原文:
Dr. Rawlings sighed a long sigh born of frustration and impatience and went wearily to the bookcase. Almost methodically he removed a large gold-titled volume of Freud's A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis and withdrew the bottle from its hiding place. The bottle was half filled with an amber fluid which jiggled pleasantly as he held it in an unsteady hand, observing with a practiced eye how gaily it sparkled in the late afternoon sunlight. Then from the cavity he also extracted a small whiskey glass.
He took these tools to his desk, poured himself a stiff one, downed it, flopped into his swivel chair and closed his eyes. Chicken farms, he thought. He felt the fiery liquid seep through him, warming his insides with its silent flame, bringing a pleasant glow of satisfaction to his mind.
He closed his eyes tighter and regarded the darkened world with a calmness that was somehow conducive to rational thought even in this irrational world. To thought and to sleep, he realized suddenly, as he found his head tilting.
He rose quickly, blinking off the effects of the liquor, and carefully returned the utensils to their proper niche behind the volume of Freud on the bookshelf. Good old Freud, he thought, always knew he'd come in handy one of these days. Then he returned to his desk to consult a small pad, and silently cursed the cruel fates that had given him patients tumbling upon one another in a ridiculously mad haste to reach the jumbled sanity of the normal world.
Why couldn't there have been a decent interval of time between them, so he could take a shower, or have a game of golf, or maybe even hang on a small one, or see a psychiatrist himself. Or maybe start that chicken farm he'd been talking about for the past two years.
He jabbed a button, said into the intercom, "Miss Austin, will you please send in the file on Mr. Charles T. Moore?"—and without waiting for an answer snapped the machine off.
Fifteen seconds later the door opened and Miss Austin walked in, a Manila folder in one lovely hand. As usual she was in an immaculately white uniform. White for purity? he wondered. It was a tight-fitting garment that clung to every curve as though hanging on for dear life, and on second thought he mentally erased the purity inscription on his mind's slate.
Miss Austin had a beautiful walk, and beautiful legs to walk on. He stared at them as she approached the desk. He always stared at them, fascinated, and she always knew he did, and she smiled that enticingly mad smile of hers that always made him want to give vent to an emotional catharsis.
God, he thought, how I'd love to psychoanalyze that woman! What a beautiful ego she must have. What a gorgeous id.
Carefully she deposited the folder on his desk, leaning forward strategically so her perfume could glide over him in intoxicating currents.
"Will that be all, Doctor Rawlings?" she asked in her honey-liquid tones.
"For now," he said, reaching for her hand and finding it. "But don't go away."
She smiled again, and gently freeing her hand, swept from the room. She looked even better from the back, if that were possible; after a few seconds deliberation he decided it wasn't possible. But it was women like Miss Austin that made him want a chicken farm, among other things. Miss Austin and a little tract of land far out in the country would be just perfect. In such a paradise he wouldn't even have to worry about the pecking order of hens. In fact, he might even get engrossed in raising things other than chickens.
Sighing again, he studied the folder before him, which did not take very long. The patient was still quite young even though he had already made a mark of sorts on the world. A theoretical mathematician, apparently. Probably thought himself a square circle on an adding machine. The psychiatrist browsed through the folder's contents again, then jabbed the buzzer.
"You can send Mr. Moore in now," he said and snapped the intercom off before Miss Austin could answer. The present moment was no time to be distracted.
Dr. Rawlings held his head in his hands and stared morosely at the desk. Then he picked up a pencil and began tapping it against an inkwell. An incongruous thought surely, pencil and inkwell—what would Freud say about that?
He decided in the same thought that he didn't give a particular damn what Freud thought about inkwells. There were times in fact when he didn't care what Freud thought about anything. There were times when all we wanted to think about was a small chicken farm, with maybe a gorgeous honey-blonde like Miss Austin to help sow a few seeds.
He looked out the window at the sky and the tops of buildings, and recalled with bitterness the patient who had claimed that he could fly, and who had tried to jump to the street forty floors below solely to prove it. It would have made a nasty splash, he thought. All the king's horses and all the king's men—Unless, of course, the patient really could fly....
He looked up, annoyed, and discovered that the door had not opened. Furiously, he jabbed the buzzer again. "Isn't Mr. Moore here yet?" he demanded, consulting his watch. "He was supposed to be here five minutes ago."
"He's here, Doctor," the receptionist's silk-and-satin tones came. "He's trying to get up enough courage to open the door."
"Oh," the psychiatrist said. He felt like adding something unprofessional, but he controlled himself. With an effort he shut off the intercom and just waited.
He looked up at the door and saw the knob turning slowly, ever so slowly. He watched its glistening facets turn in the dim natural lighting of the room, rotating as though in the slowest of slow motions.
He sighed and turned his attention to his desk top, where he discovered he had abstractedly pencilled on the blotter a four letter word not normally used in polite society. Hastily, annoyed with himself, he grabbed the pencil and used its erasing head to rub off the offending word.
When he looked up again, the door had opened the slightest crack. Damn, he thought, this job is going to drive me whacky yet. He recalled an episode of a few weeks earlier. He didn't want to, but the thought came just the same. Some of his patients had delusions so logical and systematized it was hard to prove to them that they were wrong. Sometimes it was hard to prove to yourself they were not right after all.
The woman from Mars, for example. She had actually believed that she was from the fourth planet, was really a Martian stranded here unaccountably. She had told a good straight story, but he had managed to convince her that she was not from Mars. He had persuaded her that she was an Earthling like everybody else, and that space travel of any sort was utterly impossible anyway.
He had been about to prove that there was probably no such planet as Mars when she'd decided not to come back. That was close to the time the meteorite landed a few miles away, the one that had never been found. After all, while not a usual occurrence, over-developed lungs and six fingers on each hand didn't mean—
The door edged open slightly, and an eye peered fearfully into the room. Then it swung wide, and the young man standing in the doorway let out a blastfurnace sigh that could be heard in surrounding offices.
"Come in, Mr. Moore," the psychiatrist said, "come in, close the door, sit down."
Mr. Moore did all these things with normal speed and in the proper order, but he did have a tendency to sit on the edge of his chair, as though he were sitting on a cliff and might topple over at any moment. The psychiatrist doodled on his pad impatiently.
"Well now, just what seems to be the trouble?"
Mr. Moore wet his lips. His face was white. He said, "I'm a mathematician. I work at the University."
"Oh," the other said, bringing to voice facts he'd read a few minutes before. "You're that Charles T. Moore, the one whose picture was in the paper a short time ago. Something about mathematics, I remember."
Moore nodded.
"Einstein, wasn't it?" the psychiatrist mused. "Something I don't understand, Einstein."
"It's not easy," Moore agreed. "That's what started my difficulty."
生成:
Dr. Rawlings slouched in his leather chair, the weight of another long day pressing down on his shoulders. The clock on his desk ticked relentlessly, each second a reminder of the parade of troubled minds that had marched through his office. He glanced at the corner of his desk drawer, knowing that just behind it lay a small bottle of whiskey, his secret companion through these trying times.

With a furtive glance towards the closed door, he reached for the drawer. His fingers trembled slightly as he retrieved the bottle, unscrewing the cap with practiced ease. The amber liquid sloshed invitingly as he poured a generous measure into his coffee mug. The rich aroma of whiskey mingled with the stale scent of coffee, creating a bittersweet perfume that filled his nostrils.

As he took a sip, savoring the burning sensation as it slid down his throat, Dr. Rawlings allowed his mind to wander. He pictured himself far from this suffocating office, away from the endless stream of neuroses and complexes that threatened to overwhelm him. In his mind's eye, he saw a quaint farmhouse, surrounded by rolling green hills. Chickens pecked contentedly at the ground, their soft clucking a soothing melody compared to the cacophony of human misery he dealt with daily.

The fantasy was so vivid he could almost feel the warmth of the sun on his face, smell the earthy scent of freshly tilled soil. In this idyllic setting, there were no more patients, no more delving into the darkest corners of the human psyche. Just him, the chickens, and blessed silence.

A sharp knock at the door jolted him back to reality. Hastily, he shoved the whiskey bottle back into its hiding place and straightened his tie.

"Come in," he called, his voice betraying none of the turmoil within.

The door opened, and Miss Austin stepped into the room. Dr. Rawlings felt his pulse quicken at the sight of her, as it always did. She was a vision in her crisp white blouse and pencil skirt, her blonde hair neatly pinned back. He allowed himself a moment to admire the graceful curve of her neck, the way her lips quirked into a small smile as she met his gaze.

"Dr. Rawlings," she said, her voice professional yet warm, "Mr. Moore is here for his appointment. Shall I send him in?"

Rawlings nodded, forcing himself to look away from Miss Austin's captivating presence. "Yes, thank you, Miss Austin. Give me just a moment to prepare."

As she turned to leave, he couldn't help but watch her go, his eyes tracing the sway of her hips. He knew it was unprofessional, knew that his attraction to his assistant was a complication he could ill afford. But in moments like these, with the whiskey warming his blood and his defenses lowered, he allowed himself to indulge in the fantasy.

He imagined Miss Austin not as his assistant, but as his partner on that chicken farm. He pictured her laughing in the sunlight, her hair loose and windswept, her eyes sparkling with joy. In this daydream, there was no professional boundary between them, no ethical considerations to navigate. Just two people, free to explore the connection that crackled between them.

But reality intruded once again as Miss Austin's voice floated through the intercom. "Dr. Rawlings, Mr. Moore is ready to come in now."

Rawlings sighed, pushing away the remnants of his fantasy. He straightened the papers on his desk, adopting the mask of the competent, compassionate psychiatrist that his patients expected to see. "Send him in, please," he replied, his voice steady and assured.

The door opened slowly, almost hesitantly, and Charles T. Moore shuffled into the room. He was a small man, hunched as if carrying an invisible burden on his narrow shoulders. His eyes, magnified behind thick glasses, darted nervously around the room before finally settling on Dr. Rawlings.

"Good afternoon, Mr. Moore," Rawlings said, gesturing to the couch across from his desk. "Please, make yourself comfortable."

Moore perched on the edge of the couch, his hands fidgeting in his lap. "Thank you, Doctor," he murmured, his voice barely above a whisper.

Rawlings studied his patient, noting the pallor of his skin, the dark circles under his eyes that spoke of sleepless nights. He had seen many brilliant minds crumble under the weight of their own intelligence, and he wondered if Moore was destined to join their ranks.

"Now, Mr. Moore," Rawlings began, his tone gentle yet probing, "why don't you tell me what brings you here today?"

Moore's gaze dropped to his hands, which were twisting together in an almost painful manner. "It's... it's difficult to explain, Doctor," he said, his voice trembling slightly. "It all started with my work, you see. My research into Einstein's theories and complex mathematics."

Rawlings leaned forward, his interest piqued despite his earlier weariness. "Go on," he encouraged.

Moore took a deep breath, as if steeling himself for what was to come. "I've always been fascinated by the nature of reality, Doctor. The fundamental building blocks of the universe. But the deeper I delved into my research, the more I began to... to see things differently."

"How so?" Rawlings asked, his pen poised over his notepad.

"It's as if... as if the very fabric of reality has started to unravel before my eyes," Moore continued, his words coming faster now, tumbling out in a rush. "I see patterns everywhere, Doctor. In the way people move, in the arrangement of objects in a room. It's like I can see the underlying mathematics of the universe, and it's... it's overwhelming."

Rawlings nodded, jotting down notes as Moore spoke. He had heard similar complaints from other patients over the years, usually those in high-stress, intellectually demanding fields. But there was something about Moore's intensity, the wild look in his eyes, that gave Rawlings pause.

"And how does this affect your daily life, Mr. Moore?" he asked, keeping his voice calm and steady.

Moore let out a brittle laugh. "Affect it? Doctor, it's consumed it entirely. I can barely leave my house anymore. Every time I step outside, I'm bombarded by these patterns, these... these equations. It's like the world is screaming its secrets at me, and I can't make it stop."

As Moore spoke, Rawlings felt a familiar sense of exhaustion creeping over him. He had heard variations of this story countless times before - brilliant minds unable to cope with the weight of their own intelligence, retreating into paranoia and delusion. Part of him wanted to reach for the whiskey again, to dull the edges of his own frustration and helplessness.

But he pushed the urge aside, focusing instead on the trembling man before him. This was why he had become a psychiatrist in the first place - to help those who were struggling, to guide them back from the brink of despair.

"Mr. Moore," Rawlings said gently, "what you're experiencing sounds incredibly distressing. But I want you to know that you're not alone in this. We're going to work together to help you manage these thoughts and feelings."

Moore looked up, a glimmer of hope in his eyes. "You... you believe me, Doctor? You don't think I'm crazy?"

Rawlings smiled reassuringly. "The human mind is a complex and wonderful thing, Mr. Moore. Sometimes, especially for those as intellectually gifted as yourself, it can become overwhelmed. What you're experiencing is your mind's way of trying to make sense of the vast amount of information you're processing. It doesn't make you crazy - it makes you human."

As he spoke, Rawlings felt some of his earlier weariness lifting. This was why he endured the long days, the parade of troubled souls. For moments like these, when he could offer a lifeline to someone drowning in the depths of their own mind.

"Now," he continued, leaning forward slightly, "let's start at the beginning. Tell me more about your research, and when you first started noticing these patterns."

As Moore began to speak, his words coming easier now, Rawlings settled into his role. The fantasies of chicken farms and inappropriate relationships with his assistant faded into the background. Here, in this moment, he was exactly where he needed to be.

The session continued, with Moore gradually opening up about his experiences. He spoke of sleepless nights spent poring over complex equations, of moments when the lines between mathematics and reality seemed to blur. Rawlings listened attentively, asking questions and offering gentle reassurances when needed.

As the hour drew to a close, Rawlings could see a subtle change in Moore's demeanor. The man's shoulders had relaxed slightly, and there was a hint of relief in his eyes.

"Mr. Moore," Rawlings said as their time came to an end, "I believe we've made a good start today. I'd like to see you again next week, if that's alright with you. In the meantime, I'm going to give you some exercises to help ground you when you feel overwhelmed by these patterns."

Moore nodded eagerly. "Thank you, Doctor. I... I feel better already, just having someone listen and understand."

As Moore left the office, Rawlings sat back in his chair, feeling a mix of exhaustion and satisfaction. He glanced at the drawer where the whiskey was hidden, but for the first time that day, he felt no urge to reach for it.

Instead, he buzzed the intercom. "Miss Austin, could you please schedule Mr. Moore for the same time next week?"

"Of course, Doctor," came the reply. "Is there anything else you need?"

Rawlings paused for a moment, thinking of his earlier fantasies. "No, Miss Austin," he said finally. "That will be all. Thank you."

As he turned back to his notes, preparing for his next patient, Dr. Rawlings felt a renewed sense of purpose. The chicken farm could wait. For now, there was important work to be done right here.
summary:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the passage:

Dr. Rawlings, a psychiatrist, is depicted as weary and frustrated with his professional life, finding temporary solace in a hidden bottle of whiskey. He muses about various personal desires, such as starting a chicken farm and his unprofessional attraction to his assistant, Miss Austin. Despite his internal struggles, he prepares to see his next patient, Mr. Charles T. Moore, a mathematician who has been hesitant about entering the room. The passage ends with Moore beginning to explain that his difficulties started with his work related to Einstein and complex mathematics.

Key Points:
1. **Dr. Rawlings' Character**: A tired and frustrated psychiatrist who secretly drinks whiskey and fantasizes about a simpler life.
2. **Miss Austin**: Dr. Rawlings' attractive assistant, who is aware of his attentions.
3. **Professional Frustration**: Rawlings is overwhelmed by the constant influx of patients and longs for a break.
4. **Patient Introduction**: Mr. Charles T. Moore, a mathematician struggling with issues stemming from his work involving Einstein.
5. **Themes**: Professional burnout, unfulfilled desires, and the complexities of dealing with patients' mental health.

原文:
Dr. Rawlings sighed a long sigh born of frustration and impatience and went wearily to the bookcase. Almost methodically he removed a large gold-titled volume of Freud's A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis and withdrew the bottle from its hiding place. The bottle was half filled with an amber fluid which jiggled pleasantly as he held it in an unsteady hand, observing with a practiced eye how gaily it sparkled in the late afternoon sunlight. Then from the cavity he also extracted a small whiskey glass.
He took these tools to his desk, poured himself a stiff one, downed it, flopped into his swivel chair and closed his eyes. Chicken farms, he thought. He felt the fiery liquid seep through him, warming his insides with its silent flame, bringing a pleasant glow of satisfaction to his mind.
He closed his eyes tighter and regarded the darkened world with a calmness that was somehow conducive to rational thought even in this irrational world. To thought and to sleep, he realized suddenly, as he found his head tilting.
He rose quickly, blinking off the effects of the liquor, and carefully returned the utensils to their proper niche behind the volume of Freud on the bookshelf. Good old Freud, he thought, always knew he'd come in handy one of these days. Then he returned to his desk to consult a small pad, and silently cursed the cruel fates that had given him patients tumbling upon one another in a ridiculously mad haste to reach the jumbled sanity of the normal world.
Why couldn't there have been a decent interval of time between them, so he could take a shower, or have a game of golf, or maybe even hang on a small one, or see a psychiatrist himself. Or maybe start that chicken farm he'd been talking about for the past two years.
He jabbed a button, said into the intercom, "Miss Austin, will you please send in the file on Mr. Charles T. Moore?"—and without waiting for an answer snapped the machine off.
Fifteen seconds later the door opened and Miss Austin walked in, a Manila folder in one lovely hand. As usual she was in an immaculately white uniform. White for purity? he wondered. It was a tight-fitting garment that clung to every curve as though hanging on for dear life, and on second thought he mentally erased the purity inscription on his mind's slate.
Miss Austin had a beautiful walk, and beautiful legs to walk on. He stared at them as she approached the desk. He always stared at them, fascinated, and she always knew he did, and she smiled that enticingly mad smile of hers that always made him want to give vent to an emotional catharsis.
God, he thought, how I'd love to psychoanalyze that woman! What a beautiful ego she must have. What a gorgeous id.
Carefully she deposited the folder on his desk, leaning forward strategically so her perfume could glide over him in intoxicating currents.
"Will that be all, Doctor Rawlings?" she asked in her honey-liquid tones.
"For now," he said, reaching for her hand and finding it. "But don't go away."
She smiled again, and gently freeing her hand, swept from the room. She looked even better from the back, if that were possible; after a few seconds deliberation he decided it wasn't possible. But it was women like Miss Austin that made him want a chicken farm, among other things. Miss Austin and a little tract of land far out in the country would be just perfect. In such a paradise he wouldn't even have to worry about the pecking order of hens. In fact, he might even get engrossed in raising things other than chickens.
Sighing again, he studied the folder before him, which did not take very long. The patient was still quite young even though he had already made a mark of sorts on the world. A theoretical mathematician, apparently. Probably thought himself a square circle on an adding machine. The psychiatrist browsed through the folder's contents again, then jabbed the buzzer.
"You can send Mr. Moore in now," he said and snapped the intercom off before Miss Austin could answer. The present moment was no time to be distracted.
Dr. Rawlings held his head in his hands and stared morosely at the desk. Then he picked up a pencil and began tapping it against an inkwell. An incongruous thought surely, pencil and inkwell—what would Freud say about that?
He decided in the same thought that he didn't give a particular damn what Freud thought about inkwells. There were times in fact when he didn't care what Freud thought about anything. There were times when all we wanted to think about was a small chicken farm, with maybe a gorgeous honey-blonde like Miss Austin to help sow a few seeds.
He looked out the window at the sky and the tops of buildings, and recalled with bitterness the patient who had claimed that he could fly, and who had tried to jump to the street forty floors below solely to prove it. It would have made a nasty splash, he thought. All the king's horses and all the king's men—Unless, of course, the patient really could fly....
He looked up, annoyed, and discovered that the door had not opened. Furiously, he jabbed the buzzer again. "Isn't Mr. Moore here yet?" he demanded, consulting his watch. "He was supposed to be here five minutes ago."
"He's here, Doctor," the receptionist's silk-and-satin tones came. "He's trying to get up enough courage to open the door."
"Oh," the psychiatrist said. He felt like adding something unprofessional, but he controlled himself. With an effort he shut off the intercom and just waited.
He looked up at the door and saw the knob turning slowly, ever so slowly. He watched its glistening facets turn in the dim natural lighting of the room, rotating as though in the slowest of slow motions.
He sighed and turned his attention to his desk top, where he discovered he had abstractedly pencilled on the blotter a four letter word not normally used in polite society. Hastily, annoyed with himself, he grabbed the pencil and used its erasing head to rub off the offending word.
When he looked up again, the door had opened the slightest crack. Damn, he thought, this job is going to drive me whacky yet. He recalled an episode of a few weeks earlier. He didn't want to, but the thought came just the same. Some of his patients had delusions so logical and systematized it was hard to prove to them that they were wrong. Sometimes it was hard to prove to yourself they were not right after all.
The woman from Mars, for example. She had actually believed that she was from the fourth planet, was really a Martian stranded here unaccountably. She had told a good straight story, but he had managed to convince her that she was not from Mars. He had persuaded her that she was an Earthling like everybody else, and that space travel of any sort was utterly impossible anyway.
He had been about to prove that there was probably no such planet as Mars when she'd decided not to come back. That was close to the time the meteorite landed a few miles away, the one that had never been found. After all, while not a usual occurrence, over-developed lungs and six fingers on each hand didn't mean—
The door edged open slightly, and an eye peered fearfully into the room. Then it swung wide, and the young man standing in the doorway let out a blastfurnace sigh that could be heard in surrounding offices.
"Come in, Mr. Moore," the psychiatrist said, "come in, close the door, sit down."
Mr. Moore did all these things with normal speed and in the proper order, but he did have a tendency to sit on the edge of his chair, as though he were sitting on a cliff and might topple over at any moment. The psychiatrist doodled on his pad impatiently.
"Well now, just what seems to be the trouble?"
Mr. Moore wet his lips. His face was white. He said, "I'm a mathematician. I work at the University."
"Oh," the other said, bringing to voice facts he'd read a few minutes before. "You're that Charles T. Moore, the one whose picture was in the paper a short time ago. Something about mathematics, I remember."
Moore nodded.
"Einstein, wasn't it?" the psychiatrist mused. "Something I don't understand, Einstein."
"It's not easy," Moore agreed. "That's what started my difficulty."

The passage ends with Moore beginning to explain that his difficulties started with his work related to Einstein and complex mathematics.

Key Points:
1. **Dr. Rawlings' Character**: A tired and frustrated psychiatrist who secretly drinks whiskey and fantasizes about a simpler life.
2. **Miss Austin**: Dr. Rawlings' attractive assistant, who is aware of his attentions.
3. **Professional Frustration**: Rawlings is overwhelmed by the constant influx of patients and longs for a break.
4. **Patient Introduction**: Mr. Charles T. Moore, a mathematician struggling with issues stemming from his work involving Einstein.
5. **Themes**: Professional burnout, unfulfilled desires, and the complexities of dealing with patients' mental health.

原文:
An elegant carriage stood in the middle of the road with a pair of spirited grey horses; there was no one in it, and the coachman had got off his box and stood by; the horses were being held by the bridle.... A mass of people had gathered round, the police standing in front. One of them held a lighted lantern which he was turning on something lying close to the wheels. Everyone was talking, shouting, exclaiming; the coachman seemed at a loss and kept repeating:
“What a misfortune! Good Lord, what a misfortune!”
Raskolnikov pushed his way in as far as he could, and succeeded at last in seeing the object of the commotion and interest. On the ground a man who had been run over lay apparently unconscious, and covered with blood; he was very badly dressed, but not like a workman. Blood was flowing from his head and face; his face was crushed, mutilated and disfigured. He was evidently badly injured.
“Merciful heaven!” wailed the coachman, “what more could I do? If I’d been driving fast or had not shouted to him, but I was going quietly, not in a hurry. Everyone could see I was going along just like everybody else. A drunken man can’t walk straight, we all know.... I saw him crossing the street, staggering and almost falling. I shouted again and a second and a third time, then I held the horses in, but he fell straight under their feet! Either he did it on purpose or he was very tipsy.... The horses are young and ready to take fright... they started, he screamed... that made them worse. That’s how it happened!”
“That’s just how it was,” a voice in the crowd confirmed.
“He shouted, that’s true, he shouted three times,” another voice declared.
“Three times it was, we all heard it,” shouted a third.
But the coachman was not very much distressed and frightened. It was evident that the carriage belonged to a rich and important person who was awaiting it somewhere; the police, of course, were in no little anxiety to avoid upsetting his arrangements. All they had to do was to take the injured man to the police station and the hospital. No one knew his name.
Meanwhile Raskolnikov had squeezed in and stooped closer over him. The lantern suddenly lighted up the unfortunate man’s face. He recognised him.
“I know him! I know him!” he shouted, pushing to the front. “It’s a government clerk retired from the service, Marmeladov. He lives close by in Kozel’s house.... Make haste for a doctor! I will pay, see?” He pulled money out of his pocket and showed it to the policeman. He was in violent agitation.
The police were glad that they had found out who the man was. Raskolnikov gave his own name and address, and, as earnestly as if it had been his father, he besought the police to carry the unconscious Marmeladov to his lodging at once.
“Just here, three houses away,” he said eagerly, “the house belongs to Kozel, a rich German. He was going home, no doubt drunk. I know him, he is a drunkard. He has a family there, a wife, children, he has one daughter.... It will take time to take him to the hospital, and there is sure to be a doctor in the house. I’ll pay, I’ll pay! At least he will be looked after at home... they will help him at once. But he’ll die before you get him to the hospital.” He managed to slip something unseen into the policeman’s hand. But the thing was straightforward and legitimate, and in any case help was closer here. They raised the injured man; people volunteered to help.
Kozel’s house was thirty yards away. Raskolnikov walked behind, carefully holding Marmeladov’s head and showing the way.
“This way, this way! We must take him upstairs head foremost. Turn round! I’ll pay, I’ll make it worth your while,” he muttered.
Katerina Ivanovna had just begun, as she always did at every free moment, walking to and fro in her little room from window to stove and back again, with her arms folded across her chest, talking to herself and coughing. Of late she had begun to talk more than ever to her eldest girl, Polenka, a child of ten, who, though there was much she did not understand, understood very well that her mother needed her, and so always watched her with her big clever eyes and strove her utmost to appear to understand. This time Polenka was undressing her little brother, who had been unwell all day and was going to bed. The boy was waiting for her to take off his shirt, which had to be washed at night. He was sitting straight and motionless on a chair, with a silent, serious face, with his legs stretched out straight before him—heels together and toes turned out.
He was listening to what his mother was saying to his sister, sitting perfectly still with pouting lips and wide-open eyes, just as all good little boys have to sit when they are undressed to go to bed. A little girl, still younger, dressed literally in rags, stood at the screen, waiting for her turn. The door on to the stairs was open to relieve them a little from the clouds of tobacco smoke which floated in from the other rooms and brought on long terrible fits of coughing in the poor, consumptive woman. Katerina Ivanovna seemed to have grown even thinner during that week and the hectic flush on her face was brighter than ever.
“You wouldn’t believe, you can’t imagine, Polenka,” she said, walking about the room, “what a happy luxurious life we had in my papa’s house and how this drunkard has brought me, and will bring you all, to ruin! Papa was a civil colonel and only a step from being a governor; so that everyone who came to see him said, ‘We look upon you, Ivan Mihailovitch, as our governor!’ When I... when...” she coughed violently, “oh, cursed life,” she cried, clearing her throat and pressing her hands to her breast, “when I... when at the last ball... at the marshal’s... Princess Bezzemelny saw me—who gave me the blessing when your father and I were married, Polenka—she asked at once ‘Isn’t that the pretty girl who danced the shawl dance at the breaking-up?’ (You must mend that tear, you must take your needle and darn it as I showed you, or to-morrow—cough, cough, cough—he will make the hole bigger,” she articulated with effort.) “Prince Schegolskoy, a kammerjunker, had just come from Petersburg then... he danced the mazurka with me and wanted to make me an offer next day; but I thanked him in flattering expressions and told him that my heart had long been another’s. That other was your father, Polya; papa was fearfully angry.... Is the water ready? Give me the shirt, and the stockings! Lida,” said she to the youngest one, “you must manage without your chemise to-night... and lay your stockings out with it... I’ll wash them together.... How is it that drunken vagabond doesn’t come in? He has worn his shirt till it looks like a dish-clout, he has torn it to rags! I’d do it all together, so as not to have to work two nights running! Oh, dear! (Cough, cough, cough, cough!) Again! What’s this?” she cried, noticing a crowd in the passage and the men, who were pushing into her room, carrying a burden. “What is it? What are they bringing? Mercy on us!”
生成:
The grey horses snorted and stamped their hooves against the cobblestones, their sleek bodies quivering with nervous energy. The carriage they pulled stood motionless in the middle of the bustling street, its polished wood gleaming in the late afternoon sun. A crowd had gathered, their faces a mixture of shock, curiosity, and morbid fascination.

On the ground, sprawled in an unnatural position, lay a man. His clothes were shabby and stained, his face pale and slack. A thin trickle of blood seeped from the corner of his mouth, pooling on the dirty street beneath his head. The man was motionless, save for the shallow rise and fall of his chest.

The coachman stood nearby, wringing his hands and casting anxious glances between the prone figure and the gathering crowd. His face was flushed, whether from exertion or distress, it was hard to tell. "I tried to warn him," he exclaimed, his voice trembling. "He stumbled right into the path of the horses. I shouted, I pulled on the reins, but it was too late. The drink, it must have been the drink that addled his senses."

As the crowd pressed closer, a young man pushed his way through. His eyes widened with recognition as he took in the scene before him. "Marmeladov," he breathed, dropping to his knees beside the injured man. "It's Marmeladov, the retired clerk."

The young man was Raskolnikov, his face etched with concern as he assessed the damage. Marmeladov's breathing was labored, his skin clammy to the touch. Without hesitation, Raskolnikov turned to the crowd. "We must get him home," he declared. "It's not far from here. He needs immediate care."

A murmur rippled through the onlookers. "Shouldn't we take him to the hospital?" someone suggested.

Raskolnikov shook his head vehemently. "No, no. His home is closer. Every moment counts. I'll pay for a doctor myself if need be." He reached into his pocket, producing a handful of coins. Pressing them into the hand of a nearby policeman, he urged, "Please, ensure we have a clear path. This man's life may depend on it."

The policeman, swayed by the weight of the coins and the urgency in Raskolnikov's voice, began to disperse the crowd. "Make way! Make way!" he shouted, his authoritative tone brooking no argument.

With the help of several bystanders, Raskolnikov carefully lifted Marmeladov. The injured man groaned softly, his head lolling against Raskolnikov's shoulder. The small procession made its way through the streets, Raskolnikov leading the way with determined steps.

As they approached Marmeladov's home, the sounds of a woman's voice could be heard, shrill and agitated. Raskolnikov's brow furrowed, recognizing the tone of desperation that colored the words.

Inside the cramped, dimly lit apartment, Katerina Ivanovna paced back and forth. Her thin frame was wracked with periodic coughing fits, each one leaving her gasping for air. Despite her obvious illness, her eyes burned with a fierce intensity as she addressed her children.

"Polenka, mind the soup," she instructed her eldest daughter. "And Lidochka, for heaven's sake, stop fidgeting with your dress. We may be poor, but we needn't look slovenly."

The children, wide-eyed and quiet, hurried to obey their mother's commands. Katerina Ivanovna's gaze softened slightly as she watched them, a wistful expression crossing her face.

"Ah, children," she sighed, her voice taking on a dreamy quality. "You cannot imagine the life we once had. Your father and I, we were respected, admired even. I wore the finest silks, attended grand parties..." Her words trailed off as another coughing fit seized her.

As the fit subsided, Katerina Ivanovna's expression hardened once more. "But look at us now," she spat bitterly. "Reduced to this hovel, barely scraping by. And why? Because your father cannot resist the lure of the bottle. Every kopeck, every morsel of food, sacrificed to his insatiable thirst."

She resumed her pacing, her thin hands twisting together in agitation. "If only he could see reason, if only he could understand the suffering he causes. But no, night after night, he stumbles home, reeking of cheap vodka, mumbling his pathetic apologies."

The children remained silent, their young faces etched with a mixture of fear and resignation. They had heard this lament many times before, knew better than to interrupt their mother's tirade.

Suddenly, a commotion outside the door caught their attention. Katerina Ivanovna paused mid-stride, her brow furrowing in confusion. The door burst open, and a crowd of people surged into the small room, carrying a limp figure.

"Semyon Zakharovich!" Katerina Ivanovna cried out, recognizing her husband despite his battered state. "What has happened? What have you done now?"

Raskolnikov, still supporting Marmeladov's head, spoke quickly. "There's been an accident, madam. Your husband was struck by a carriage. He needs immediate care."

Katerina Ivanovna's face paled, her anger giving way to shock and fear. "Lay him here," she commanded, gesturing to the threadbare sofa. As they settled Marmeladov onto the worn cushions, she turned to her eldest daughter. "Polenka, run for the doctor. Tell him it's urgent."

As Polenka darted out the door, Katerina Ivanovna knelt beside her husband. Her hands, trembling slightly, hovered over his bruised face. "Oh, Semyon," she whispered, her voice thick with emotion. "What am I to do with you?"

Raskolnikov watched the scene unfold, a mixture of pity and discomfort washing over him. He had known of the Marmeladovs' dire circumstances, but seeing it firsthand was another matter entirely. The poverty, the desperation, the lingering ghosts of better days – it all pressed in on him, threatening to overwhelm his senses.

Yet, as he observed Katerina Ivanovna tending to her husband, Raskolnikov felt a stirring of something he had not experienced in a long time: empathy. Despite her harsh words earlier, despite the years of hardship and disappointment, there was genuine concern in her touch, real fear in her eyes.

"Is there anything else I can do?" Raskolnikov asked, his voice soft.

Katerina Ivanovna looked up, seeming to notice him properly for the first time. "You've done more than enough, sir," she replied, her tone grateful despite its weariness. "Thank you for bringing him home."

Raskolnikov nodded, feeling suddenly awkward in the cramped, emotionally charged room. "I'll wait outside for the doctor," he said, moving towards the door. "Please, let me know if you need anything else."

As he stepped into the hallway, closing the door gently behind him, Raskolnikov leaned against the wall and closed his eyes. The events of the past hour swirled in his mind – the accident, the crowd, the policeman's bribe, the Marmeladovs' pitiful home. He had acted on instinct, driven by a sudden, overwhelming need to help. But now, in the quiet of the hallway, doubt began to creep in.

What good had he really done? Marmeladov's injuries were severe; there was no guarantee he would survive. And even if he did, what then? Back to the bottle, back to squandering what little the family had? And Katerina Ivanovna, with her consumptive cough and bitter memories, how long could she go on?

Raskolnikov's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of hurried footsteps. He opened his eyes to see Polenka returning with a harried-looking doctor in tow. As they rushed past him into the apartment, Raskolnikov caught a glimpse of the scene inside: Katerina Ivanovna, still kneeling by the sofa, her head bowed in what might have been prayer; the younger children huddled in a corner, their eyes wide with fear; and Marmeladov, pale and still, his labored breathing the only sign of life.

The door closed once more, leaving Raskolnikov alone in the hallway. He knew he should leave, that his presence was no longer required or even desired. Yet something kept him rooted to the spot. Perhaps it was a sense of responsibility, having been the one to bring Marmeladov home. Or perhaps it was something deeper, a newfound connection to the suffering of others that he couldn't quite shake.

Whatever the reason, Raskolnikov remained, his back pressed against the peeling wallpaper, his ears straining to catch any sound from within the apartment. The muffled voices of the doctor and Katerina Ivanovna, punctuated by Marmeladov's occasional groans, created a somber symphony of human struggle.

As he waited, Raskolnikov's mind drifted to his own circumstances. He, too, lived in poverty, knew the gnawing pain of hunger and the crushing weight of despair. Yet seeing the Marmeladovs' situation had stirred something in him, a realization that perhaps his own troubles were not as insurmountable as he had believed.

The door creaked open, startling Raskolnikov from his reverie. The doctor emerged, his face grave. "He's stable for now," he informed Raskolnikov, assuming he was a relative or close friend. "But the next few hours will be critical. I've left instructions with his wife."

Raskolnikov nodded, thanking the doctor. As the medical man descended the stairs, Raskolnikov hesitated, his hand on the apartment door. Should he go back inside? Offer more help? Or had he done all he could?

In the end, he chose to leave, slipping quietly down the stairs and out into the evening air. The street was quieter now, the excitement of the accident long since dissipated. As Raskolnikov walked away from the Marmeladovs' building, he felt changed, though he couldn't quite articulate how.

The encounter had awakened something in him, a spark of humanity that had long lain dormant. Whether it would grow into a flame of compassion or be snuffed out by the harsh realities of his world remained to be seen. But for now, Raskolnikov walked on, carrying with him the weight of what he had witnessed and the faint, flickering hope of redemption.
summary:
Certainly! This passage describes a dramatic scene involving a carriage accident in a bustling street. The carriage, drawn by spirited grey horses, has run over an unconscious, badly injured man lying on the ground. The coachman, distressed but not excessively so, explains that the victim stumbled drunkenly into the horses' path despite his warnings.

Raskolnikov, pushing through the crowd, recognizes the injured man as Marmeladov, a retired government clerk. Displaying urgency and compassion, Raskolnikov insists on taking Marmeladov to his nearby home rather than the hospital, believing he can receive immediate care there. He even offers to pay for a doctor and bribes a policeman to ensure swift action.

The scene shifts to Marmeladov's impoverished home, where his consumptive wife, Katerina Ivanovna, paces the room and laments their ruined lives, particularly due to Marmeladov's alcoholism. She nostalgically recalls her once-privileged life, instructs her children in household tasks, and endures severe fits of coughing. The arrival of the injured Marmeladov carried by the crowd shocks her, and the passage ends with her exclamation of distress.

In summary, the passage juxtaposes a chaotic accident scene with the backdrop of a family's dire situation, highlighting themes of poverty, desperation, and Raskolnikov's moment of empathy.

原文:
An elegant carriage stood in the middle of the road with a pair of spirited grey horses; there was no one in it, and the coachman had got off his box and stood by; the horses were being held by the bridle.... A mass of people had gathered round, the police standing in front. One of them held a lighted lantern which he was turning on something lying close to the wheels. Everyone was talking, shouting, exclaiming; the coachman seemed at a loss and kept repeating:
“What a misfortune! Good Lord, what a misfortune!”
Raskolnikov pushed his way in as far as he could, and succeeded at last in seeing the object of the commotion and interest. On the ground a man who had been run over lay apparently unconscious, and covered with blood; he was very badly dressed, but not like a workman. Blood was flowing from his head and face; his face was crushed, mutilated and disfigured. He was evidently badly injured.
“Merciful heaven!” wailed the coachman, “what more could I do? If I’d been driving fast or had not shouted to him, but I was going quietly, not in a hurry. Everyone could see I was going along just like everybody else. A drunken man can’t walk straight, we all know.... I saw him crossing the street, staggering and almost falling. I shouted again and a second and a third time, then I held the horses in, but he fell straight under their feet! Either he did it on purpose or he was very tipsy.... The horses are young and ready to take fright... they started, he screamed... that made them worse. That’s how it happened!”
“That’s just how it was,” a voice in the crowd confirmed.
“He shouted, that’s true, he shouted three times,” another voice declared.
“Three times it was, we all heard it,” shouted a third.
But the coachman was not very much distressed and frightened. It was evident that the carriage belonged to a rich and important person who was awaiting it somewhere; the police, of course, were in no little anxiety to avoid upsetting his arrangements. All they had to do was to take the injured man to the police station and the hospital. No one knew his name.
Meanwhile Raskolnikov had squeezed in and stooped closer over him. The lantern suddenly lighted up the unfortunate man’s face. He recognised him.
“I know him! I know him!” he shouted, pushing to the front. “It’s a government clerk retired from the service, Marmeladov. He lives close by in Kozel’s house.... Make haste for a doctor! I will pay, see?” He pulled money out of his pocket and showed it to the policeman. He was in violent agitation.
The police were glad that they had found out who the man was. Raskolnikov gave his own name and address, and, as earnestly as if it had been his father, he besought the police to carry the unconscious Marmeladov to his lodging at once.
“Just here, three houses away,” he said eagerly, “the house belongs to Kozel, a rich German. He was going home, no doubt drunk. I know him, he is a drunkard. He has a family there, a wife, children, he has one daughter.... It will take time to take him to the hospital, and there is sure to be a doctor in the house. I’ll pay, I’ll pay! At least he will be looked after at home... they will help him at once. But he’ll die before you get him to the hospital.” He managed to slip something unseen into the policeman’s hand. But the thing was straightforward and legitimate, and in any case help was closer here. They raised the injured man; people volunteered to help.
Kozel’s house was thirty yards away. Raskolnikov walked behind, carefully holding Marmeladov’s head and showing the way.
“This way, this way! We must take him upstairs head foremost. Turn round! I’ll pay, I’ll make it worth your while,” he muttered.
Katerina Ivanovna had just begun, as she always did at every free moment, walking to and fro in her little room from window to stove and back again, with her arms folded across her chest, talking to herself and coughing. Of late she had begun to talk more than ever to her eldest girl, Polenka, a child of ten, who, though there was much she did not understand, understood very well that her mother needed her, and so always watched her with her big clever eyes and strove her utmost to appear to understand. This time Polenka was undressing her little brother, who had been unwell all day and was going to bed. The boy was waiting for her to take off his shirt, which had to be washed at night. He was sitting straight and motionless on a chair, with a silent, serious face, with his legs stretched out straight before him—heels together and toes turned out.
He was listening to what his mother was saying to his sister, sitting perfectly still with pouting lips and wide-open eyes, just as all good little boys have to sit when they are undressed to go to bed. A little girl, still younger, dressed literally in rags, stood at the screen, waiting for her turn. The door on to the stairs was open to relieve them a little from the clouds of tobacco smoke which floated in from the other rooms and brought on long terrible fits of coughing in the poor, consumptive woman. Katerina Ivanovna seemed to have grown even thinner during that week and the hectic flush on her face was brighter than ever.
“You wouldn’t believe, you can’t imagine, Polenka,” she said, walking about the room, “what a happy luxurious life we had in my papa’s house and how this drunkard has brought me, and will bring you all, to ruin! Papa was a civil colonel and only a step from being a governor; so that everyone who came to see him said, ‘We look upon you, Ivan Mihailovitch, as our governor!’ When I... when...” she coughed violently, “oh, cursed life,” she cried, clearing her throat and pressing her hands to her breast, “when I... when at the last ball... at the marshal’s... Princess Bezzemelny saw me—who gave me the blessing when your father and I were married, Polenka—she asked at once ‘Isn’t that the pretty girl who danced the shawl dance at the breaking-up?’ (You must mend that tear, you must take your needle and darn it as I showed you, or to-morrow—cough, cough, cough—he will make the hole bigger,” she articulated with effort.) “Prince Schegolskoy, a kammerjunker, had just come from Petersburg then... he danced the mazurka with me and wanted to make me an offer next day; but I thanked him in flattering expressions and told him that my heart had long been another’s. That other was your father, Polya; papa was fearfully angry.... Is the water ready? Give me the shirt, and the stockings! Lida,” said she to the youngest one, “you must manage without your chemise to-night... and lay your stockings out with it... I’ll wash them together.... How is it that drunken vagabond doesn’t come in? He has worn his shirt till it looks like a dish-clout, he has torn it to rags! I’d do it all together, so as not to have to work two nights running! Oh, dear! (Cough, cough, cough, cough!) Again! What’s this?” she cried, noticing a crowd in the passage and the men, who were pushing into her room, carrying a burden. “What is it? What are they bringing? Mercy on us!”

原文:
The journey from Paris to Dresden at that time took five days and nights. On the German frontier, near Forbach, we met with stormy weather and snow, a greeting which seemed inhospitable after the spring we had already enjoyed in Paris. And, indeed, as we continued our journey through our native land once more, we found much to dishearten us, and I could not help thinking that the Frenchmen who on leaving Germany breathed more freely on reaching French soil, and unbuttoned their coats, as though passing from winter into summer, were not so very foolish after all, seeing that we, for our part, were now compelled to seek protection against this conspicuous change of temperature by being very careful to put on sufficient clothing. The unkindness of the elements became perfect torture when, later on, between Frankfort and Leipzig, we were swept into the stream of visitors to the Great Easter Fair.
The pressure on the mail-coaches was so great, that for two days and a night, amid ceaseless storm, snow and rain, we were continually changing from one wretched ‘substitute’ to another, thus turning our journey into an adventure of almost the same type as our former voyage at sea.
One solitary flash of brightness was afforded by our view of the Wartburg, which we passed during the only sunlit hour of this journey. The sight of this mountain fastness, which, from the Fulda side, is clearly visible for a long time, affected me deeply. A neighbouring ridge further on I at once christened the Horselberg, and as we drove through the valley, pictured to myself the scenery for the third act of my Tannhäuser. This scene remained so vividly in my mind, that long afterwards I was able to give Desplechin, the Parisian scene-painter, exact details when he was working out the scenery under my direction. If I had already been impressed by the significance of the fact that my first journey through the German Rhine district, so famous in legend, should have been made on my way home from Paris, it seemed an even more ominous coincidence that my first sight of Wartburg, which was so rich in historical and mythical associations, should come just at this moment. The view so warmed my heart against wind and weather, Jews and the Leipzig Fair, that in the end I arrived, on 12th April, 1842, safe and sound, with my poor, battered, half-frozen wife, in that selfsame city of Dresden which I had last seen on the occasion of my sad separation from my Minna, and my departure for my northern place of exile.
We put up at the ‘Stadt Gotha’ inn. The city, in which such momentous years of my childhood and boyhood had been spent, seemed cold and dead beneath the influences of the wild, gloomy weather. Indeed, everything there that could remind me of my youth seemed dead. No hospitable house received us. We found my wife’s parents living in cramped and dingy lodgings in very straitened circumstances, and were obliged at once to look about for a small abode for ourselves. This we found in the Topfergasse for twenty-one marks a month. After paying the necessary business visits in connection with Rienzi, and making arrangements for Minna during my brief absence, I set out on 15th April direct for Leipzig, where I saw my mother and family for the first time in six years.
During this period, which had been so eventful for my own life, my mother had undergone a great change in her domestic position through the death of Rosalie. She was living in a pleasant roomy flat near the Brockhaus family, where she was free from all those household cares to which, owing to her large family, she had devoted so many years of anxious thought. Her bustling energy, which had almost amounted to hardness, had entirely given place to a natural cheerfulness and interest in the family prosperity of her married daughters. For the blissful calm of this happy old age she was mainly indebted to the affectionate care of her son-in-law, Friedrich Brockhaus, to whom I expressed my heartfelt thanks for his goodness. She was exceedingly astonished and pleased to see me unexpectedly enter her room. Any bitterness that ever existed between us had utterly vanished, and her only complaint was that she could not put me up in her house, instead of my brother Julius, the unfortunate goldsmith, who had none of the qualities that could make him a suitable companion for her. She was full of hope for the success of my undertaking, and felt this confidence strengthened by the favourable prophecy which our dear Rosalie had made about me shortly before her sad death.
For the present, however, I only stayed a few days in Leipzig, as I had first to visit Berlin in order to make definite arrangements with Count Redern for the performance of the Fliegender Holländer. As I have already observed, I was here at once destined to learn that the Count was on the point of retiring from the directorship, and he accordingly referred me for all further decisions to the new director, Küstner, who had not yet arrived in Berlin. I now suddenly realised what this strange circumstance meant, and knew that, so far as the Berlin negotiations went, I might as well have remained in Paris. This impression was in the main confirmed by a visit to Meyerbeer, who, I found, regarded my coming to Berlin as over hasty. Nevertheless, he behaved in a kind and friendly manner, only regretting that he was just on the point of ‘going away,’ a state in which I always found him whenever I visited him again in Berlin.
Mendelssohn was also in the capital about this time, having been appointed one of the General Musical Directors to the King of Prussia. I also sought him out, having been previously introduced to him in Leipzig. He informed me that he did not believe his work would prosper in Berlin, and that he would rather go back to Leipzig. I made no inquiry about the fate of the score of my great symphony performed at Leipzig in earlier days, which I had more or less forced upon him so many years ago. On the other hand, he did not betray to me any signs of remembering that strange offering. In the midst of the lavish comforts of his home he struck me as cold, yet it was not so much that he repelled me as that I recoiled from him. I also paid a visit to Rellstab, to whom I had a letter of introduction from his trusty publisher, my brother-in-law Brockhaus. Here it was not so much smug ease that I encountered; I doubtless felt repulsed more by the fact that he showed no inclination whatever to interest himself in my affairs.
生成:
The journey from Paris to Dresden in the spring of 1842 was one I would not soon forget. As our carriage rumbled across the border into Germany, the skies darkened, and a biting wind whipped through the air, as if nature itself sought to repel our intrusion. The once-picturesque countryside transformed into a bleak landscape, matching the growing unease in my heart.

We had set out with high hopes, my wife and I, eager to escape the stifling atmosphere of Paris and seek new opportunities in the German states. But as we pressed on through increasingly inhospitable terrain, I began to question the wisdom of our decision. The Great Easter Fair loomed ahead, casting a long shadow over our travels. Towns and villages along our route buzzed with anticipation, their streets clogged with merchants and traders hurrying to reach Leipzig in time for the grand event.

Our progress slowed to a crawl as we navigated the congested roads. Each jolting bump and sudden lurch of the carriage sent waves of discomfort through my weary body. The unpredictability of our journey gnawed at my nerves, leaving me tense and irritable. My wife, ever patient, tried to soothe my frayed nerves with gentle words and reassuring touches, but even her calming presence could not fully dispel the cloud of anxiety that had settled over me.

As we wound our way through Thuringia, a sight emerged that momentarily lifted my spirits. The Wartburg castle, perched majestically atop a forested hill, came into view. Its ancient stones seemed to glow with an inner light, defying the gloomy weather that surrounded us. I felt a spark of inspiration ignite within me, my mind already racing with possibilities for future compositions. The castle's rich history and legends whispered to me, promising tales of chivalry and romance that begged to be set to music.

But the moment of creative clarity was fleeting. As we approached Dresden, the city's cold and unwelcoming facade seemed to mock our hopes for a warm reception. The streets were eerily quiet, save for the occasional hurried footsteps of locals eager to escape the chill. The grand buildings that lined the avenues, normally so impressive, now loomed over us like stern sentinels, their windows dark and uninviting.

We searched in vain for suitable lodgings, our fatigue growing with each rejection. Finally, we settled for a modest inn on the outskirts of the city, its shabby exterior doing little to lift our spirits. The room was small and drafty, but it was a refuge from the hostile world outside. As I lay awake that night, listening to the wind howl outside our window, I couldn't shake the feeling that we were unwelcome intruders in a land that had once felt like home.

The following days were a blur of business meetings and social calls, each interaction leaving me feeling more disconnected from the world I had once known. The city's residents seemed caught up in their own concerns, barely sparing a glance for the travel-worn couple in their midst. I longed for a friendly face, a word of encouragement, anything to dispel the growing sense of alienation that threatened to overwhelm me.

With our affairs in Dresden concluded, we pressed on to Leipzig. The anticipation of reuniting with my family after six long years provided a glimmer of hope in the otherwise dreary journey. As we approached the city, memories of my childhood flooded back, bittersweet reminders of a simpler time.

Our arrival at my mother's home was a moment of pure joy amidst the challenges of our trip. Her face, lined with age but still radiant with love, broke into a wide smile as she embraced us. The years melted away as we shared stories and laughter, the warmth of family temporarily banishing the chill that had settled in my bones.

To my relief and gratitude, I found my mother's living conditions much improved since my last visit. My brother-in-law, a kind and generous man, had taken it upon himself to ensure her comfort in her twilight years. The modest but well-appointed apartment was a testament to his care, and I felt a weight lift from my shoulders knowing that she was well looked after.

As we sat around the dinner table that evening, savoring home-cooked dishes that tasted of nostalgia, I allowed myself to relax for the first time since leaving Paris. The familiar cadence of my mother's voice, the warm glow of the lamplight, and the gentle hum of conversation created a cocoon of comfort that I had sorely missed.

But duty called, and all too soon, I found myself bidding farewell to my family and boarding a train bound for Berlin. The purpose of this leg of the journey was to arrange a performance of my latest work, "The Flying Dutchman." I had high hopes for the opera, believing it to be my finest work yet, and I was eager to secure a prestigious venue for its debut.

However, as the train rattled northward, doubts began to creep in. News had reached me that Count Redern, a key figure in Berlin's musical scene, was retiring. His departure threw my carefully laid plans into disarray, and I found myself questioning the very purpose of my trip. Would anyone in Berlin be interested in the work of an unknown composer from Paris?

Upon arrival in the Prussian capital, I wasted no time in seeking out influential figures in the music world. My first encounter was with Giacomo Meyerbeer, a composer of considerable renown. I approached him with a mixture of hope and trepidation, aware of his influence and eager for his approval.

Meyerbeer received me cordially enough, but I sensed a certain coolness beneath his polite exterior. As I explained the concept behind "The Flying Dutchman," I watched his expression carefully, searching for any sign of interest or enthusiasm. But his face remained impassive, his comments noncommittal. When I left his presence, I felt deflated, my confidence in my work shaken.

Seeking to bolster my spirits, I arranged a meeting with Felix Mendelssohn, whose genius I had long admired. To my surprise and delight, Mendelssohn proved to be far more receptive to my ideas. He listened intently as I described the opera, his eyes lighting up with genuine interest. We spent hours discussing music theory and composition, and for a brief, shining moment, I felt as though I had found a kindred spirit in this strange city.

But as I made my way back to my lodgings that evening, the euphoria of my encounter with Mendelssohn began to fade. The streets of Berlin, grand and imposing, seemed to close in around me. Passersby hurried past, their faces set in expressions of grim determination. I felt like a ghost, invisible and insubstantial, drifting through a world that had no place for me.

The following days were a whirlwind of meetings and negotiations, each one leaving me feeling more drained and disconnected than the last. I found myself longing for the comfort of my wife's presence, for the familiar streets of Paris, even for the challenging journey that had brought us to this point. The world of high society and professional music-making, which I had once viewed with such reverence, now seemed cold and artificial.

As I sat in my rented room on the final night of my stay in Berlin, I reflected on the tumultuous journey that had brought me to this point. The harsh weather, the unpredictable travel conditions, the mixed receptions from my peers – all of it had taken its toll. Yet beneath the exhaustion and disappointment, I felt a spark of determination growing.

I realized that this journey, challenging though it had been, had strengthened my resolve. The obstacles I had faced, the moments of doubt and alienation, had all served to clarify my artistic vision. I knew now, with a certainty that surprised me, that I would continue to compose, to create, to push the boundaries of my art – not for the approval of others, but for the pure joy of musical expression.

As I packed my bags for the return journey to Paris, I felt a sense of anticipation building within me. The road ahead would not be easy, but I was ready to face whatever challenges lay in store. With the memory of the Wartburg castle's inspiration, the warmth of my family's love, and the fire of my own determination, I would forge ahead, creating music that spoke to the depths of the human experience.

The journey from Paris to Dresden, and the subsequent travels through Germany, had been more than just a physical odyssey. It had been a journey of self-discovery, a test of will, and ultimately, a reaffirmation of my purpose as an artist. As I boarded the train that would carry me back to France, I knew that while the journey had ended, my true artistic voyage was only just beginning.
summary:
This passage recounts a challenging journey from Paris to Dresden in 1842. The narrator describes encountering inhospitable weather upon crossing into Germany and experiencing severe discomfort and unpredictability while traveling amid the pressures of the Great Easter Fair. Despite the harsh conditions, the narrator finds solace in viewing the Wartburg castle, which sparks creative inspiration for future work.

Arriving in Dresden, the city appears cold and unwelcoming, heightening the narrator's sense of alienation. The couple, finding no hospitable welcome, stays in modest accommodations. After dealing with some business matters, the narrator continues to Leipzig, reuniting with family after a six-year absence. Here, they find the narrator's mother in improved living conditions, thanks to the support of her son-in-law.

The passage concludes with the narrator's trip to Berlin to arrange a performance of their work, "The Flying Dutchman." Complications arise as Count Redern is retiring, leading to doubts about the purpose of the trip. Encounters with notable figures like Meyerbeer and Mendelssohn reveal mixed receptions, underscoring the narrator’s ongoing challenges and sense of disconnection in professional and social spheres.

原文:
The journey from Paris to Dresden at that time took five days and nights. On the German frontier, near Forbach, we met with stormy weather and snow, a greeting which seemed inhospitable after the spring we had already enjoyed in Paris. And, indeed, as we continued our journey through our native land once more, we found much to dishearten us, and I could not help thinking that the Frenchmen who on leaving Germany breathed more freely on reaching French soil, and unbuttoned their coats, as though passing from winter into summer, were not so very foolish after all, seeing that we, for our part, were now compelled to seek protection against this conspicuous change of temperature by being very careful to put on sufficient clothing. The unkindness of the elements became perfect torture when, later on, between Frankfort and Leipzig, we were swept into the stream of visitors to the Great Easter Fair.
The pressure on the mail-coaches was so great, that for two days and a night, amid ceaseless storm, snow and rain, we were continually changing from one wretched ‘substitute’ to another, thus turning our journey into an adventure of almost the same type as our former voyage at sea.
One solitary flash of brightness was afforded by our view of the Wartburg, which we passed during the only sunlit hour of this journey. The sight of this mountain fastness, which, from the Fulda side, is clearly visible for a long time, affected me deeply. A neighbouring ridge further on I at once christened the Horselberg, and as we drove through the valley, pictured to myself the scenery for the third act of my Tannhäuser. This scene remained so vividly in my mind, that long afterwards I was able to give Desplechin, the Parisian scene-painter, exact details when he was working out the scenery under my direction. If I had already been impressed by the significance of the fact that my first journey through the German Rhine district, so famous in legend, should have been made on my way home from Paris, it seemed an even more ominous coincidence that my first sight of Wartburg, which was so rich in historical and mythical associations, should come just at this moment. The view so warmed my heart against wind and weather, Jews and the Leipzig Fair, that in the end I arrived, on 12th April, 1842, safe and sound, with my poor, battered, half-frozen wife, in that selfsame city of Dresden which I had last seen on the occasion of my sad separation from my Minna, and my departure for my northern place of exile.
We put up at the ‘Stadt Gotha’ inn. The city, in which such momentous years of my childhood and boyhood had been spent, seemed cold and dead beneath the influences of the wild, gloomy weather. Indeed, everything there that could remind me of my youth seemed dead. No hospitable house received us. We found my wife’s parents living in cramped and dingy lodgings in very straitened circumstances, and were obliged at once to look about for a small abode for ourselves. This we found in the Topfergasse for twenty-one marks a month. After paying the necessary business visits in connection with Rienzi, and making arrangements for Minna during my brief absence, I set out on 16th April direct for Leipzig, where I saw my mother and family for the first time in six years.
During this period, which had been so eventful for my own life, my mother had undergone a great change in her domestic position through the death of Rosalie. She was living in a pleasant roomy flat near the Brockhaus family, where she was free from all those household cares to which, owing to her large family, she had devoted so many years of anxious thought. Her bustling energy, which had almost amounted to hardness, had entirely given place to a natural cheerfulness and interest in the family prosperity of her married daughters. For the blissful calm of this happy old age she was mainly indebted to the affectionate care of her son-in-law, Friedrich Brockhaus, to whom I expressed my heartfelt thanks for his goodness. She was exceedingly astonished and pleased to see me unexpectedly enter her room. Any bitterness that ever existed between us had utterly vanished, and her only complaint was that she could not put me up in her house, instead of my brother Julius, the unfortunate goldsmith, who had none of the qualities that could make him a suitable companion for her. She was full of hope for the success of my undertaking, and felt this confidence strengthened by the favourable prophecy which our dear Rosalie had made about me shortly before her sad death.
For the present, however, I only stayed a few days in Leipzig, as I had first to visit Berlin in order to make definite arrangements with Count Redern for the performance of the Fliegender Holländer. As I have already observed, I was here at once destined to learn that the Count was on the point of retiring from the directorship, and he accordingly referred me for all further decisions to the new director, Küstner, who had not yet arrived in Berlin. I now suddenly realised what this strange circumstance meant, and knew that, so far as the Berlin negotiations went, I might as well have remained in Paris. This impression was in the main confirmed by a visit to Meyerbeer, who, I found, regarded my coming to Berlin as over hasty. Nevertheless, he behaved in a kind and friendly manner, only regretting that he was just on the point of ‘going away,’ a state in which I always found him whenever I visited him again in Berlin.
Mendelssohn was also in the capital about this time, having been appointed one of the General Musical Directors to the King of Prussia. I also sought him out, having been previously introduced to him in Leipzig. He informed me that he did not believe his work would prosper in Berlin, and that he would rather go back to Leipzig. I made no inquiry about the fate of the score of my great symphony performed at Leipzig in earlier days, which I had more or less forced upon him so many years ago. On the other hand, he did not betray to me any signs of remembering that strange offering. In the midst of the lavish comforts of his home he struck me as cold, yet it was not so much that he repelled me as that I recoiled from him. I also paid a visit to Rellstab, to whom I had a letter of introduction from his trusty publisher, my brother-in-law Brockhaus. Here it was not so much smug ease that I encountered; I doubtless felt repulsed more by the fact that he showed no inclination whatever to interest himself in my affairs.
