生成:
Hwæt! Ic secgan wille of Phoebus, se æþelinga beorhtost,
þa he on eorþan wunode mid mannum.
He wæs se lustbaeresta hæleþ, fæger on ansyne,
ond on bogan geornful, mid flanum gefrætwod.

Phoebus wæs se mærost scytta, se þe ofersceotende
þone wyrm Python ofsloh, se þe eorþan swealh.
His scearpne strael he sende þurh þæs wyrmes heafod,
ond swa he mannkynn fram þæm egsan alysde.

Ac he næs na æfter gefeohte geornful,
ac on dreamcræfte he wæs se gleawesta.
His hearpe wæs of golde geworht, mid seolfre gerenod,
ond þa strengas wæron of seolcnum þrædum gespunnen.

Þonne he his fingras on þa hearpestrengas asette,
þonne aras swylc dream swylce englas sungen.
His stefn wæs swa swete swa huniges beobread,
ond ealle þa þe hine gehyrdon wurdon mid wynne afyllede.

Phoebus hæfde ænne fugol, hwit swa snaw,
se þe mihte sprecan ond singan swa fægere swa ænig mann.
Þes hrefn wæs his deorling, his freond ond his hordweard,
ond he hine lærde ealle his cræftas ond wisdom.

Eac swylce hæfde Phoebus ane cwene, seo wæs his mod-lufu,
fæger swa sunne on sumeres dæge.
He hi lufode ofer ealle oþre þing on eorþan,
ond he wolde hi æfre mid him habban.

Ac Phoebus wæs geomor ond ealda,
for þæm þe he ondred þæt heo him ungetreowe wære.
He hi beheold dæges ond nihtes, ond ne geþafode
þæt ænig oþer wer hire genealæhte.

Ac swa hit oft gesceoteþ þæt se þe oþerne healdeþ
on bendum, he hine sylfne bindeþ.
Swa dyde Phoebus, se þe his cwene swa strange heold,
þæt heo þæs þe geornor wilnode hire sylfre willan to donne.

Þa gelamp hit sume dæge þæt Phoebus ut ferde
to huntaþe, swa his þeaw wæs.
His cwene belaf æt ham, ana ond ungeheald,
ond heo sona sende æfter hire leofestan cnihte.

Þes cniht wæs læssa þonne Phoebus on hade,
ac he wæs geong ond lustbære, ond hire heorte gehwearf to him.
Heo hine underfeng on hire bure, ond hi twegen
drugon heora unrihtlican lufe dihlice.

Ac se hwita hrefn geseah eall þæt hi dydon,
ond he hit geheold on his mode oþ þæt Phoebus ham com.
Þa Phoebus ham com, þa flæh se cniht ut þurh þæt ægþyrl,
ond seo cwen hi gearwode swylce nan þing ne wære.

Ac se hrefn ne mihte his tunge gehealdan,
ac he sang: "Cuckoo! Cuckoo!" ofer eall þæt hus.
Phoebus gehyrde þæs fugoles sang ond he axode:
"Hwæt beteknaþ þis sang, min leofa fugol?"

Se hrefn þa sæde eall þæt he geseah,
hu seo cwen hire unrihtlice forlegenes.
Phoebus wearþ þa swa yrre þæt he his mod ne mihte gehealdan,
ac he genam his bogan ond his scearpne strael.

Mid þæm strael he ofsceat his agne cwene,
seo þe him ær wæs seo leofeste on eallum middangearde.
Heo feoll dead to flore, ond hire blod fleow
ofer þæt marmstanas flet, read swa rose.

Þa Phoebus geseah hwæt he gedon hæfde,
þa awearp he his bogan ond his strealwæpen.
He tobræc his gyldenan hearpe, ond toslat his seolcene strengas,
ond he cwæþ þæt he næfre ma ne wolde singan ne gleowan.

He awende his ansyne fram þæm hwitan hrefne,
se þe him þa soþan spel brohte.
He cwæþ: "Aweg þu, ungesæliga fugol, þu eart min feond!
For þinum wordum ic hæbbe min leofoste ofslegen."

He awearp þone hrefn ut of his huse,
ond cwæþ þæt he sceolde æfre forþ habban sweart feþera
for his yfelan bodunge. Ond siþþan næfron
nan hwit hrefn gesewen on eorþan.

Phoebus þa forlet ealle his ærran weorcu,
he ne wolde ma bogan bendan ne hearpe hearpian.
He becom to anum westenne, þær he ana wunode
monige gear, beweop his cwene ond his ærdæda.

Þus we magon oncnawan þæt nis nan mann swa wis
þæt he mæge wifes mod gehealdan, gif heo wile awendan.
For þæm þe wif is swylce wilde deor, þæt ne mæg beon getæmed,
ac hit wile æfter his agenum willan irnan.

Eac we magon leornian þæt yrre is se mæsta feond,
se þe mæg forspillan ealles mannes gesælþa on anre hwile.
For þæm yrre adwæscþ wisdom, ond ablent þæs mannes mod,
þæt he ne mæg geseon hwæt riht is to donne.

Ond þeah þe mann hæbbe ealle woruldgesælþa,
gif he næfþ wisdom to his mode, he mæg eaþe forleosan eall.
For þæm se wisdom is betere þonne gold oþþe seolfor,
ond he mæg þone mann gelædan to eallum godum.

Ac se þe his mod ne mæg gehealdan, ac læt hit irnan
æfter his lustum, he biþ gelic þæm unstillum sæ,
seo þe biþ drefed mid windum ond mid yþum,
ond ne mæg nan þing on hire gestandan.

Swa biþ þæs mannes mod þe ne mæg hine sylfne gehealdan,
ac læt hine lædan æfter his yfelum gewilnungum.
He biþ unstille ond ungeþwære, ond ne mæg nanþing godes gedon,
ac he biþ æfre on ymbhogan ond on sorge.

For þæm we sculon leornian wisdom ond geþyld,
þæt we magon ure mod gehealdan on ælcere frecednysse.
Ond we sculon biddan þone ælmihtigan God
þæt he us gehealde fram yfelum gewilnungum ond fram yrre.

For þæm se þe hæfþ Godes gife on his mode,
he mæg eaþe oferswþian ealle costnunga.
He biþ gestæþþig on ælcum gewinne, ond gesælig on life,
ond he mæg becuman to þæm ecan life æfter þissum.

Þus endaþ þis spel be Phoebus ond his cwene,
ond be þæm hwitan hrefne þe wearþ to sweartum.
Uton we nu leornian wisdom of heora ungesælþum,
þæt we ne feallan on swylce frecednyssa.
summary:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the passage:

The passage recounts the story of Phoebus (Apollo) when he lived on Earth, highlighting his excellent attributes: he was the most pleasant bachelor, a skilled archer who killed the serpent Python, and a talented musician and singer. Phoebus had a white crow that could speak and sing wonderfully. Phoebus also had a wife whom he loved deeply, but he was jealous and overly protective.

Despite his efforts to keep her faithful, his wife was untrue, taking another lover of lower status while Phoebus was away. The white crow witnessed the infidelity and reported it to Phoebus upon his return, singing "Cuckoo" to signify his wife's betrayal. Phoebus, devastated by this revelation, killed his wife in a fit of rage, destroyed his musical instruments, and swore off his former pursuits. The story explores themes of jealousy, infidelity, and the futility of trying to control someone's natural tendencies.

原文:
When Phoebus dwelled here in earth adown,
As olde bookes make mentioun,
He was the moste lusty* bacheler *pleasant
Of all this world, and eke* the best archer. *also
He slew Python the serpent, as he lay
Sleeping against the sun upon a day;
And many another noble worthy deed
He with his bow wrought, as men maye read.
Playen he could on every minstrelsy,
And singe, that it was a melody
To hearen of his cleare voice the soun’.
Certes the king of Thebes, Amphioun,
That with his singing walled the city,
Could never singe half so well as he.
Thereto he was the seemlieste man
That is, or was since that the world began;
What needeth it his features to descrive?
For in this world is none so fair alive.
He was therewith full fill’d of gentleness,
Of honour, and of perfect worthiness.
This Phoebus, that was flower of bach’lery,
As well in freedom* as in chivalry, *generosity
For his disport, in sign eke of victory
Of Python, so as telleth us the story,
Was wont to bearen in his hand a bow.
Now had this Phoebus in his house a crow,
Which in a cage he foster’d many a day,
And taught it speaken, as men teach a jay.
White was this crow, as is a snow-white swan,
And counterfeit the speech of every man
He coulde, when he shoulde tell a tale.
Therewith in all this world no nightingale
Ne coulde by an hundred thousand deal* *part
Singe so wondrous merrily and well.
Now had this Phoebus in his house a wife;
Which that he loved more than his life.
And night and day did ever his diligence
Her for to please, and do her reverence:
Save only, if that I the sooth shall sayn,
Jealous he was, and would have kept her fain.
For him were loth y-japed* for to be; *tricked, deceived
And so is every wight in such degree;
But all for nought, for it availeth nought.
A good wife, that is clean of work and thought,
Should not be kept in none await* certain: *observation
And truely the labour is in vain
To keep a shrewe,* for it will not be. *ill-disposed woman
This hold I for a very nicety,* *sheer folly
To spille* labour for to keepe wives; *lose
Thus writen olde clerkes in their lives.
But now to purpose, as I first began.
This worthy Phoebus did all that he can
To please her, weening, through such pleasance,
And for his manhood and his governance,
That no man should have put him from her grace;
But, God it wot, there may no man embrace
As to distrain* a thing, which that nature *succeed in constraining
Hath naturally set in a creature.
Take any bird, and put it in a cage,
And do all thine intent, and thy corage,* *what thy heart prompts
To foster it tenderly with meat and drink
Of alle dainties that thou canst bethink,
And keep it all so cleanly as thou may;
Although the cage of gold be never so gay,
Yet had this bird, by twenty thousand fold,
Lever* in a forest, both wild and cold, *rather
Go eate wormes, and such wretchedness.
For ever this bird will do his business
T’escape out of his cage when that he may:
His liberty the bird desireth aye. <3>
Let take a cat, and foster her with milk
And tender flesh, and make her couch of silk,
And let her see a mouse go by the wall,
Anon she weiveth* milk, and flesh, and all, *forsaketh
And every dainty that is in that house,
Such appetite hath she to eat the mouse.
Lo, here hath kind* her domination, *nature
And appetite flemeth* discretion. *drives out
A she-wolf hath also a villain’s kind
The lewedeste wolf that she may find,
Or least of reputation, will she take
In time when *her lust* to have a make.* *she desires *mate
All these examples speak I by* these men *with reference to
That be untrue, and nothing by women.
For men have ever a lik’rous appetite
On lower things to perform their delight
Than on their wives, be they never so fair,
Never so true, nor so debonair.* *gentle, mild
Flesh is so newefangled, *with mischance,* *ill luck to it*
That we can in no thinge have pleasance
That *souneth unto* virtue any while. *accords with
This Phoebus, which that thought upon no guile,
Deceived was for all his jollity;
For under him another hadde she,
A man of little reputation,
Nought worth to Phoebus in comparison.
The more harm is; it happens often so,
Of which there cometh muche harm and woe.
And so befell, when Phoebus was absent,
His wife anon hath for her leman* sent. *unlawful lover
Her leman! certes that is a knavish speech.
Forgive it me, and that I you beseech.
The wise Plato saith, as ye may read,
The word must needs accorde with the deed;
If men shall telle properly a thing,
The word must cousin be to the working.
I am a boistous* man, right thus I say. *rough-spoken, downright
There is no difference truely
Betwixt a wife that is of high degree
(If of her body dishonest she be),
And any poore wench, other than this
(If it so be they worke both amiss),
But, for* the gentle is in estate above, *because
She shall be call’d his lady and his love;
And, for that other is a poor woman,
She shall be call’d his wench and his leman:
And God it wot, mine owen deare brother,
Men lay the one as low as lies the other.
Right so betwixt a *titleless tyrant* *usurper*
And an outlaw, or else a thief errant, *wandering
The same I say, there is no difference
(To Alexander told was this sentence),
But, for the tyrant is of greater might
By force of meinie* for to slay downright, *followers
And burn both house and home, and make all plain,* *level
Lo, therefore is he call’d a capitain;
And, for the outlaw hath but small meinie,
And may not do so great an harm as he,
Nor bring a country to so great mischief,
Men calle him an outlaw or a thief.
But, for I am a man not textuel, *learned in texts
I will not tell of texts never a deal;* *whit
I will go to my tale, as I began.
When Phoebus’ wife had sent for her leman,
Anon they wroughten all their *lust volage.* *light or rash pleasure*
This white crow, that hung aye in the cage,
Beheld their work, and said never a word;
And when that home was come Phoebus the lord,
This crowe sung, “Cuckoo, cuckoo, cuckoo!”
“What? bird,” quoth Phoebus, “what song sing’st thou now?
Wert thou not wont so merrily to sing,
That to my heart it was a rejoicing
To hear thy voice? alas! what song is this?”
“By God,” quoth he, “I singe not amiss.
Phoebus,” quoth he, “for all thy worthiness,
For all thy beauty, and all thy gentleness,
For all thy song, and all thy minstrelsy,
*For all thy waiting, bleared is thine eye* *despite all thy watching,
With one of little reputation, thou art befooled*
Not worth to thee, as in comparison,
The mountance* of a gnat, so may I thrive; *value
For on thy bed thy wife I saw him swive.”
What will ye more? the crow anon him told,
By sade* tokens, and by wordes bold, *grave, trustworthy
How that his wife had done her lechery,
To his great shame and his great villainy;
And told him oft, he saw it with his eyen.
This Phoebus gan awayward for to wrien;* *turn aside
Him thought his woeful hearte burst in two.
His bow he bent, and set therein a flo,* *arrow
And in his ire he hath his wife slain;
This is th’ effect, there is no more to sayn.
For sorrow of which he brake his minstrelsy,
Both harp and lute, gitern* and psaltery; *guitar

And after that thus spake he to the crow.
summary:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the passage:

The passage recounts the story of Phoebus (Apollo) when he lived on Earth, highlighting his excellent attributes: he was the most pleasant bachelor, a skilled archer who killed the serpent Python, and a talented musician and singer. Phoebus had a white crow that could speak and sing wonderfully. Phoebus also had a wife whom he loved deeply, but he was jealous and overly protective.

Despite his efforts to keep her faithful, his wife was untrue, taking another lover of lower status while Phoebus was away. The white crow witnessed the infidelity and reported it to Phoebus upon his return, singing "Cuckoo" to signify his wife's betrayal. Phoebus, devastated by this revelation, killed his wife in a fit of rage, destroyed his musical instruments, and swore off his former pursuits. The story explores themes of jealousy, infidelity, and the futility of trying to control someone's natural tendencies.

原文:
1. No Knowledge without Discernment.
Another faculty we may take notice of in our minds is that of DISCERNING and DISTINGUISHING between the several ideas it has. It is not enough to have a confused perception of something in general. Unless the mind had a distinct perception of different objects and their qualities, it would be capable of very little knowledge, though the bodies that affect us were as busy about us as they are now, and the mind were continually employed in thinking. On this faculty of distinguishing one thing from another depends the evidence and certainty of several, even very general, propositions, which have passed for innate truths;—because men, overlooking the true cause why those propositions find universal assent, impute it wholly to native uniform impressions; whereas it in truth depends upon this clear discerning faculty of the mind, whereby it PERCEIVES two ideas to be the same, or different. But of this more hereafter.
2. The Difference of Wit and Judgment.
How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.
3. Clearness alone hinders Confusion.
To the well distinguishing our ideas, it chiefly contributes that they be CLEAR and DETERMINATE. And when they are so, it will not breed any confusion or mistake about them, though the senses should (as sometimes they do) convey them from the same object differently on different occasions, and so seem to err. For, though a man in a fever should from sugar have a bitter taste, which at another time would produce a sweet one, yet the idea of bitter in that man’s mind would be as clear and distinct from the idea of sweet as if he had tasted only gall. Nor does it make any more confusion between the two ideas of sweet and bitter that the same sort of body produces at one time one, and at another time another idea by the taste, than it makes a confusion in two ideas of white and sweet, or white and round, that the same piece of sugar produces them both in the mind at the same time. And the ideas of orange-colour and azure, that are produced in the mind by the same parcel of the infusion of lignum nephritium, are no less distinct ideas than those of the same colours taken from two very different bodies.
4. Comparing.
The COMPARING them one with another, in respect of extent, degrees, time, place, or any other circumstances, is another operation of the mind about its ideas, and is that upon which depends all that large tribe of ideas comprehended under RELATION; which, of how vast an extent it is, I shall have occasion to consider hereafter.
5. Brutes compare but imperfectly.
How far brutes partake in this faculty, is not easy to determine. I imagine they have it not in any great degree, for, though they probably have several ideas distinct enough, yet it seems to me to be the prerogative of human understanding, when it has sufficiently distinguished any ideas, so as to perceive them to be perfectly different, and so consequently two, to cast about and consider in what circumstances they are capable to be compared. And therefore, I think, beasts compare not their ideas further than some sensible circumstances annexed to the objects themselves. The other power of comparing, which may be observed in men, belonging to general ideas, and useful only to abstract reasonings, we may probably conjecture beasts have not.
6. Compounding.
The next operation we may observe in the mind about its ideas is COMPOSITION; whereby it puts together several of those simple ones it has received from sensation and reflection, and combines them into complex ones. Under this of composition may be reckoned also that of ENLARGING, wherein, though the composition does not so much appear as in more complex ones, yet it is nevertheless a putting several ideas together, though of the same kind. Thus, by adding several units together, we make the idea of a dozen; and putting together the repeated ideas of several perches, we frame that of a furlong.
7. Brutes compound but little.
In this also, I suppose, brutes come far short of man. For, though they take in, and retain together, several combinations of simple ideas, as possibly the shape, smell, and voice of his master make up the complex idea a dog has of him, or rather are so many distinct marks whereby he knows him; yet I do not think they do of themselves ever compound them, and make complex ideas. And perhaps even where we think they have complex ideas, it is only one simple one that directs them in the knowledge of several things, which possibly they distinguish less by their sight than we imagine. For I have been credibly informed that a bitch will nurse, play with, and be fond of young foxes, as much as, and in place of her puppies, if you can but get them once to suck her so long that her milk may go through them. And those animals which have a numerous brood of young ones at once, appear not to have any knowledge of their number; for though they are mightily concerned for any of their young that are taken from them whilst they are in sight or hearing, yet if one or two of them be stolen from them in their absence, or without noise, they appear not to miss them, or to have any sense that their number is lessened.
8. Naming.
When children have, by repeated sensations, got ideas fixed in their memories, they begin by degrees to learn the use of signs. And when they have got the skill to apply the organs of speech to the framing of articulate sounds, they begin to make use of words, to signify their ideas to others. These verbal signs they sometimes borrow from others, and sometimes make themselves, as one may observe among the new and unusual names children often give to things in the first use of language.
9. Abstraction.
The use of words then being to stand as outward mark of our internal ideas, and those ideas being taken from particular things, if every particular idea that we take up should have a distinct name, names must be endless. To prevent this, the mind makes the particular ideas received from particular objects to become general; which is done by considering them as they are in the mind such appearances,—separate from all other existences, and the circumstances of real existence, as time, place, or any other concomitant ideas. This is called ABSTRACTION, whereby ideas taken from particular beings become general representatives of all of the same kind; and their names general names, applicable to whatever exists conformable to such abstract ideas. Such precise, naked appearances in the mind, without considering how, whence, or with what others they came there, the understanding lays up (with names commonly annexed to them) as the standards to rank real existences into sorts, as they agree with these patterns, and to denominate them accordingly. Thus the same colour being observed to-day in chalk or snow, which the mind yesterday received from milk, it considers that appearance alone, makes it a representative of all of that kind; and having given it the name WHITENESS, it by that sound signifies the same quality wheresoever to be imagined or met with; and thus universals, whether ideas or terms, are made.
10. Brutes abstract not.
If it may be doubted whether beasts compound and enlarge their ideas that way to any degree; this, I think, I may be positive in,—that the power of abstracting is not at all in them; and that the having of general ideas is that which puts a perfect distinction betwixt man and brutes, and is an excellency which the faculties of brutes do by no means attain to. For it is evident we observe no footsteps in them of making use of general signs for universal ideas; from which we have reason to imagine that they have not the faculty of abstracting, or making general ideas, since they have no use of words, or any other general signs.
生成:
Eala, þu seċest micle wisdom! Ic sceal nu secgan þe of þæm ealdan gewritum, swa swa þa uðwitan hie awriton. Hlyst nu georne, for þæm þe þis is deoplic lar.

On fruman, we sculon sprecan be andgite and wisdom. Se mann þe hafað god andgit mæg tosceadan betwux mislicum geþohtum and cneowum. Þis is se fruma ealles wisdomes. Gif se mod ne mæg sweotole tosceadan betwux þingum and heora gecyndum, þonne cymð þær micel gedrefedness. Ac se þe hæfð þis cræft on his mode, he mæg oncnawan þa soðfæstnesse and gewissnesse manigra cwida, þe men oft wenað þæt hi syn acennede mid us.

Nu we willað sprecan be þæm twam cræftum þæs modes: glęawscipe and dom. Se glęawscipa mann mæg hraðe gadrian mænigfealde geþohtas, and oft he macað lustbære and wynsum biliðu on his mode. Se dom is oðer cræft: he tosceadað geþohtas geornlice, þæt þær ne sy nan gedrefedness, ac þæt eall sy sweotol on þæs mannes gescead. Men lufiaþ þone glęawscipan for his hraðum and wynsumum geþohtum, ac se wisdom soðlice secð æfter þæm deopan dome.

Hit is eac swiðe niedbehefo þæt we habban clæne and sweotole geþohtas, þæt we ne syn gedrefede. Þeah þe ure andgitu hwilon mistigiaþ, gif we habbað clæne geþohtas, we magon æfre tosceadan betwux þingum. Nim nu bysene: þeah þe se swete mete hwilon ne þince swa swete for sumre untrymnesse, þeah we witon hwæt is bitter and hwæt is swete.

Se mann hæfð eac þone cræft þæt he mæg metian geþohtas. He besceawað heora micelnysse, heora timan, heora stowa, and ealle oðre wise. Of þisum cræfte cumað mænigfealde geþohtas be þæra þinga gesceadwisnesse.

Nu we sculon sprecan be nytenum. Þa nytenu habbað sum andgit, ac hi ne magon swa geornlice metian heora geþohtas swa se mann deð. Se mann ana mæg scearpne dom habban ofer his geþohtas, and þæt lǣt hine smeagan be þæm þingum þe he næfre ne geseah mid his eagum.

Se mann hæfð eac þone cræft þæt he mæg gadrian mænige anfealda geþohtas to anum micclum geþohte. He mæg of manegum annysse wyrcan twelf, oððe hundseofontig, oððe ma. Þis is micel cræft þæs modes, and hit is gyt ungewiss hwæðer þa nytenu magon þus don. Hi magon oncnawan þa þing þe hi geseoð and gehyrað, ac hi ne wyrcað nænige niwe geþohtas of þæm ealdum.

Nim nu bysene be hundum: seo bicce mæg fedan geonga foxas mid hire meolce, gif heo næfre ær foxas ne geseah, for þæm þe heo oncnæwð þa anlicnesse betwux hire hwelpum and þæm foxum. Ac heo ne mæg na ma don þonne þæt: heo ne mæg nænige niwe geþohtas wyrcan be foxum and hundum.

Þonne cild weaxað, hi onginnað to nemnenne æghwilc þing þe hi geseoð. Hi findað oft selflice naman to þingum, for þæm þe hi willað cytðan heora ingeþoncas oðrum mannum. Þus we magon geseon hu se cræft to sprecenne is micel and niedbehefo.

Nu we cumað to þæm mæstan cræfte þæs modes: abstractio on Læden, þæt is on Englisc "aweg-alædness". Þis is se cræft þe tolǣt þone mann scearpne dom habban ofer ealle þing. For þæm þe we ne magon æghwilc þing sundorlice gemunan, we nymað þa gemeenelican hiw and gecynd of manegum þingum, and we wyrcað ane gemeenelice anlicnesse of eallum. We cweðað "treow" and we þencað na be anum treowe, ac be eallum treowum. We cweðað "mann" and we þencað be ealre menniscnesse. Þis is se hehsta cræft þæs modes, and hit todǣlð us fram nytenum.

Soðlice, þa nytenu ne habbað þisne cræft. Hi magon geseon treow, ac hi ne magon na geþencan be treow-cynne. Hi magon geseon mann, ac hi ne habbað nænne geþoht be menniscnesse. Þis is se cræft þe us lǣt sprecan be þæm þingum þe we næfre ne gesawon, and smean be þæm þingum þe we ne magon mid urum lichaman gehrinan.

Nu we habbað gesæd be þæm cræftum þæs modes. Þis is deop lar, and hit is niedbehefo þæt we hit georne smeagan. For þæm þe we syndon gesceapene to Godes anlicnesse, we sculon ure mod æfre hwettan and scearpian. We sculon leornian to toscadenne betwux godum and yfele, betwux soðe and leasunge. We sculon leornian to metienne ure geþohtas, and to wyrcenne niwe geþohtas of þæm ealdum. We sculon leornian to sprecenne sweotollice, þæt oðre menn magon ure ingeþoncas oncnawan. And ofer eall, we sculon leornian to alædenne ure geþohtas fram þæm hwilwendlicum þingum to þæm ecum þingum.

Se mann þe þus deð, he biþ soðlice wis. He mæg tosceadan betwux þæm þingum þe ætywað beforan his eagum and þæm þingum þe lutiað on his mode. He mæg oncnawan þa deopan geryna þe God hæfð gesett on gesceaftum. He mæg asmeagan be þæm heofonlicum þingum þe nænig eage ne geseah and nænige eare ne gehyrde. Þis is se ende and se fruma ealles wisdomes.

Eala, hu wundorlic is þæt mod þæt God us sealde! Hit is mare þonne ealle þas eorðlican þing, for þæm þe hit mæg befon ealle þas þing on his geþohtum. Hit mæg fleon ofer ealle gesceafta and sceawian þa heofonlican þing. Hit mæg asmeagan be Gode sylfum, þeah hit ne mæge hine fullice oncnawan on þisum life.

For þæm þe we habbað þis wundorlice mod, we sculon hit wel began. We ne sculon hit besylan mid yfelum geþohtum and unrihtum gewilnungum. We sculon hit fedan mid wisdome and mid godum weorcum. We sculon hit læran to fleonne fram þæm niþerlicum þingum to þæm uplicium þingum. We sculon hit gewenian to smeagenne be Gode and be heofenlicum þingum.

Se mann þe þus deð, he hæfð þone soðan wisdom. He mæg rihtlice and gesceadwislice libban on þisum life. He mæg geseon þa soþan lufe and þa soþan blisse þe us eallum onbidiaþ on þæm toweardan life. Þis is se ende ealles lares and ealles wisdomes: þæt we oncnawan God and hine lufian, and þæt we cumon to his rice æfter þisum life.

Nu ic hæbbe gesæd be þæm cræftum þæs modes, swa swa þa ealdan uðwitan hit awriton. Ic bidde þe þæt þu hit georne smeage, for þæm þe hit mæg þe lædan to micclum wisdome. And ic bidde God þæt he onlihte þin mod and þe getrymme on eallum godum weorcum.
summary:
Certainly! Here’s a summary of the main content of the passage:

1. **Discernment and Knowledge**: 
   - The ability to discern and distinguish between different ideas is crucial for acquiring knowledge. 
   - Confusion arises when the mind fails to distinctly perceive different objects and their qualities.
   - This faculty allows the mind to recognize the certainty and evidence of propositions, often mistaken for innate truths.

2. **Wit vs. Judgment**:
   - Wit involves assembling ideas quickly, often creating entertaining and agreeable images.
   - Judgment requires careful separation of ideas to avoid confusion and ensure clarity of reason.
   - Wit is appreciated for its immediate appeal, while judgment involves deeper analysis and truth-seeking.

3. **Clearness to Prevent Confusion**:
   - Clear and definite ideas prevent confusion, even if sensory perceptions vary.
   - For example, even if sugar tastes different under different conditions, clear ideas of "bitter" and "sweet" remain distinct.

4. **Comparing**:
   - Comparing ideas involves examining their extent, degrees, time, place, and other circumstances. 
   - This operation leads to a broad variety of relational ideas.

5. **Brutes and Comparison**:
   - Animals may have distinct ideas but do not compare them extensively.
   - Humans uniquely compare ideas beyond immediate sensory circumstances, aiding abstract reasoning.

6. **Compounding**:
   - The mind can combine simple ideas to form complex ones, such as forming a dozen from several units.
   - This faculty seems limited in animals, who may recognize combinations of simple ideas but do not create complex ideas themselves.

7. **Brutes and Compounding**:
   - Animals may recognize combinations of sensory attributes but don’t seem to create complex ideas akin to human cognition.
   - For example, a bitch may care for young foxes like her puppies if their relationship is established through nursing.

8. **Naming**:
   - As children gain ideas, they use words to signify these ideas, often creating unique names.
   - Words are used to communicate internal ideas to others.

9. **Abstraction**:
   - To manage endless particular ideas, the mind creates general ideas through abstraction, separating appearances from their specific circumstances.
   - These abstract ideas become general representatives (universals) and their corresponding terms are general names.

10. **Brutes and Abstraction**:
    - Unlike humans, animals do not seem to possess the ability to abstract or form general ideas.
    - Abstract thinking and the use of general signs, such as words, distinguish human cognition from that of brutes.

The central theme of the passage is the cognitive faculties of the human mind, particularly focusing on discernment, judgment, comparison, compounding, naming, and abstraction, and how these faculties differentiate humans from animals.

When children have, by repeated sensations, got ideas fixed in their memories, they begin by degrees to learn the use of signs. The use of words then being to stand as outward mark of our internal ideas, and those ideas being taken from particular things, if every particular idea that we take up should have a distinct name, names must be endless. To prevent this, the mind makes the particular ideas received from particular objects to become general; which is done by considering them as they are in the mind such appearances,—separate from all other existences, and the circumstances of real existence, as time, place, or any other concomitant ideas. If it may be doubted whether beasts compound and enlarge their ideas that way to any degree; this, I think, I may be positive in,—that the power of abstracting is not at all in them; and that the having of general ideas is that which puts a perfect distinction betwixt man and brutes, and is an excellency which the faculties of brutes do by no means attain to. For it is evident we observe no footsteps in them of making use of general signs for universal ideas; from which we have reason to imagine that they have not the faculty of abstracting, or making general ideas, since they have no use of words, or any other general signs.

1. **Discernment and Knowledge**: 
   - The ability to discern and distinguish between different ideas is crucial for acquiring knowledge. 
   - Confusion arises when the mind fails to distinctly perceive different objects and their qualities.
   - This faculty allows the mind to recognize the certainty and evidence of propositions, often mistaken for innate truths.

2. **Wit vs. Judgment**:
   - Wit involves assembling ideas quickly, often creating entertaining and agreeable images.
   - Judgment requires careful separation of ideas to avoid confusion and ensure clarity of reason.
   - Wit is appreciated for its immediate appeal, while judgment involves deeper analysis and truth-seeking.

3. **Clearness to Prevent Confusion**:
   - Clear and definite ideas prevent confusion, even if sensory perceptions vary.
   - For example, even if sugar tastes different under different conditions, clear ideas of "bitter" and "sweet" remain distinct.

4. **Comparing**:
   - Comparing ideas involves examining their extent, degrees, time, place, and other circumstances. 
   - This operation leads to a broad variety of relational ideas.

5. **Brutes and Comparison**:
   - Animals may have distinct ideas but do not compare them extensively.
   - Humans uniquely compare ideas beyond immediate sensory circumstances, aiding abstract reasoning.

6. **Compounding**:
   - The mind can combine simple ideas to form complex ones, such as forming a dozen from several units.
   - This faculty seems limited in animals, who may recognize combinations of simple ideas but do not create complex ideas themselves.

7. **Brutes and Compounding**:
   - Animals may recognize combinations of sensory attributes but don’t seem to create complex ideas akin to human cognition.
   - For example, a bitch may care for young foxes like her puppies if their relationship is established through nursing.

8. **Naming**:
   - As children gain ideas, they use words to signify these ideas, often creating unique names.
   - Words are used to communicate internal ideas to others.

9. **Abstraction**:
   - To manage endless particular ideas, the mind creates general ideas through abstraction, separating appearances from their specific circumstances.
   - These abstract ideas become general representatives (universals) and their corresponding terms are general names.

10. **Brutes and Abstraction**:
    - Unlike humans, animals do not seem to possess the ability to abstract or form general ideas.
    - Abstract thinking and the use of general signs, such as words, distinguish human cognition from that of brutes.

The central theme of the passage is the cognitive faculties of the human mind, particularly focusing on discernment, judgment, comparison, compounding, naming, and abstraction, and how these faculties differentiate humans from animals.

原文:
1. No Knowledge without Discernment.
Another faculty we may take notice of in our minds is that of DISCERNING and DISTINGUISHING between the several ideas it has. It is not enough to have a confused perception of something in general. Unless the mind had a distinct perception of different objects and their qualities, it would be capable of very little knowledge, though the bodies that affect us were as busy about us as they are now, and the mind were continually employed in thinking. On this faculty of distinguishing one thing from another depends the evidence and certainty of several, even very general, propositions, which have passed for innate truths;—because men, overlooking the true cause why those propositions find universal assent, impute it wholly to native uniform impressions; whereas it in truth depends upon this clear discerning faculty of the mind, whereby it PERCEIVES two ideas to be the same, or different. But of this more hereafter.
2. The Difference of Wit and Judgment.
How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.
3. Clearness alone hinders Confusion.
To the well distinguishing our ideas, it chiefly contributes that they be CLEAR and DETERMINATE. And when they are so, it will not breed any confusion or mistake about them, though the senses should (as sometimes they do) convey them from the same object differently on different occasions, and so seem to err. For, though a man in a fever should from sugar have a bitter taste, which at another time would produce a sweet one, yet the idea of bitter in that man’s mind would be as clear and distinct from the idea of sweet as if he had tasted only gall. Nor does it make any more confusion between the two ideas of sweet and bitter that the same sort of body produces at one time one, and at another time another idea by the taste, than it makes a confusion in two ideas of white and sweet, or white and round, that the same piece of sugar produces them both in the mind at the same time. And the ideas of orange-colour and azure, that are produced in the mind by the same parcel of the infusion of lignum nephritium, are no less distinct ideas than those of the same colours taken from two very different bodies.
4. Comparing.
The COMPARING them one with another, in respect of extent, degrees, time, place, or any other circumstances, is another operation of the mind about its ideas, and is that upon which depends all that large tribe of ideas comprehended under RELATION; which, of how vast an extent it is, I shall have occasion to consider hereafter.
5. Brutes compare but imperfectly.
How far brutes partake in this faculty, is not easy to determine. I imagine they have it not in any great degree, for, though they probably have several ideas distinct enough, yet it seems to me to be the prerogative of human understanding, when it has sufficiently distinguished any ideas, so as to perceive them to be perfectly different, and so consequently two, to cast about and consider in what circumstances they are capable to be compared. And therefore, I think, beasts compare not their ideas further than some sensible circumstances annexed to the objects themselves. The other power of comparing, which may be observed in men, belonging to general ideas, and useful only to abstract reasonings, we may probably conjecture beasts have not.
6. Compounding.
The next operation we may observe in the mind about its ideas is COMPOSITION; whereby it puts together several of those simple ones it has received from sensation and reflection, and combines them into complex ones. Under this of composition may be reckoned also that of ENLARGING, wherein, though the composition does not so much appear as in more complex ones, yet it is nevertheless a putting several ideas together, though of the same kind. Thus, by adding several units together, we make the idea of a dozen; and putting together the repeated ideas of several perches, we frame that of a furlong.
7. Brutes compound but little.
In this also, I suppose, brutes come far short of man. For, though they take in, and retain together, several combinations of simple ideas, as possibly the shape, smell, and voice of his master make up the complex idea a dog has of him, or rather are so many distinct marks whereby he knows him; yet I do not think they do of themselves ever compound them, and make complex ideas. And perhaps even where we think they have complex ideas, it is only one simple one that directs them in the knowledge of several things, which possibly they distinguish less by their sight than we imagine. For I have been credibly informed that a bitch will nurse, play with, and be fond of young foxes, as much as, and in place of her puppies, if you can but get them once to suck her so long that her milk may go through them. And those animals which have a numerous brood of young ones at once, appear not to have any knowledge of their number; for though they are mightily concerned for any of their young that are taken from them whilst they are in sight or hearing, yet if one or two of them be stolen from them in their absence, or without noise, they appear not to miss them, or to have any sense that their number is lessened.
8. Naming.
When children have, by repeated sensations, got ideas fixed in their memories, they begin by degrees to learn the use of signs. And when they have got the skill to apply the organs of speech to the framing of articulate sounds, they begin to make use of words, to signify their ideas to others. These verbal signs they sometimes borrow from others, and sometimes make themselves, as one may observe among the new and unusual names children often give to things in the first use of language.
9. Abstraction.
The use of words then being to stand as outward mark of our internal ideas, and those ideas being taken from particular things, if every particular idea that we take up should have a distinct name, names must be endless. To prevent this, the mind makes the particular ideas received from particular objects to become general; which is done by considering them as they are in the mind such appearances,—separate from all other existences, and the circumstances of real existence, as time, place, or any other concomitant ideas. This is called ABSTRACTION, whereby ideas taken from particular beings become general representatives of all of the same kind; and their names general names, applicable to whatever exists conformable to such abstract ideas. Such precise, naked appearances in the mind, without considering how, whence, or with what others they came there, the understanding lays up (with names commonly annexed to them) as the standards to rank real existences into sorts, as they agree with these patterns, and to denominate them accordingly. Thus the same colour being observed to-day in chalk or snow, which the mind yesterday received from milk, it considers that appearance alone, makes it a representative of all of that kind; and having given it the name WHITENESS, it by that sound signifies the same quality wheresoever to be imagined or met with; and thus universals, whether ideas or terms, are made.
12. Brutes abstract not.
If it may be doubted whether beasts compound and enlarge their ideas that way to any degree; this, I think, I may be positive in,—that the power of abstracting is not at all in them; and that the having of general ideas is that which puts a perfect distinction betwixt man and brutes, and is an excellency which the faculties of brutes do by no means attain to. For it is evident we observe no footsteps in them of making use of general signs for universal ideas; from which we have reason to imagine that they have not the faculty of abstracting, or making general ideas, since they have no use of words, or any other general signs.

原文:
Enter MATHIAS and KATHARINE. 75

MATHIAS. What make the Jew and Lodowick so private?
I fear me 'tis about fair Abigail.
[Aside.]

BARABAS. [to LODOWICK.] Yonder comes Don Mathias; let us stay: 76
He loves my daughter, and she holds him dear;
But I have sworn to frustrate both their hopes,
And be reveng'd upon the—governor.
[Aside.]
[Exit LODOWICK.]

KATHARINE. This Moor is comeliest, is he not? speak, son.

MATHIAS. No, this is the better, mother, view this well.

BARABAS. Seem not to know me here before your mother,
Lest she mistrust the match that is in hand:
When you have brought her home, come to my house;
Think of me as thy father: son, farewell.

MATHIAS. But wherefore talk'd Don Lodowick with you?

BARABAS. Tush, man! we talk'd of diamonds, not of Abigail.

KATHARINE. Tell me, Mathias, is not that the Jew?

BARABAS. As for the comment on the Maccabees,
I have it, sir, and 'tis at your command.

MATHIAS. Yes, madam, and my talk with him was 77
About the borrowing of a book or two.

KATHARINE. Converse not with him; he is cast off from heaven.—
Thou hast thy crowns, fellow.—Come, let's away.

MATHIAS. Sirrah Jew, remember the book.

BARABAS. Marry, will I, sir.
[Exeunt KATHARlNE and MATHIAS.]

FIRST OFFICER. Come, I have made a reasonable market; let's away.
[Exeunt OFFICERS with SLAVES.]

BARABAS. Now let me know thy name, and therewithal
Thy birth, condition, and profession.

ITHAMORE. Faith, sir, my birth is but mean; my name's Ithamore;
my profession what you please.

BARABAS. Hast thou no trade? then listen to my words,
And I will teach [thee] that shall stick by thee:
First, be thou void of these affections,
Compassion, love, vain hope, and heartless fear;
Be mov'd at nothing, see thou pity none,
But to thyself smile when the Christians moan.

ITHAMORE. O, brave, master! 78 I worship your nose 79 for this.

BARABAS. As for myself, I walk abroad o' nights,
And kill sick people groaning under walls:
Sometimes I go about and poison wells;
And now and then, to cherish Christian thieves,
I am content to lose some of my crowns,
That I may, walking in my gallery,
See 'em go pinion'd along by my door.
Being young, I studied physic, and began
To practice first upon the Italian;
There I enrich'd the priests with burials,
And always kept the sexton's arms in ure 80
With digging graves and ringing dead men's knells:
And, after that, was I an engineer,
And in the wars 'twixt France and Germany,
Under pretence of helping Charles the Fifth,
Slew friend and enemy with my stratagems:
Then, after that, was I an usurer,
And with extorting, cozening, forfeiting,
And tricks belonging unto brokery,
I fill'd the gaols with bankrupts in a year,
And with young orphans planted hospitals;
And every moon made some or other mad,
And now and then one hang himself for grief,
Pinning upon his breast a long great scroll
How I with interest tormented him.
But mark how I am blest for plaguing them;—
I have as much coin as will buy the town.
But tell me now, how hast thou spent thy time?

ITHAMORE. Faith, master,
In setting Christian villages on fire,
Chaining of eunuchs, binding galley-slaves.
One time I was an hostler in an inn,
And in the night-time secretly would I steal
To travellers' chambers, and there cut their throats:
Once at Jerusalem, where the pilgrims kneel'd,
I strewed powder on the marble stones,
And therewithal their knees would rankle so,
That I have laugh'd a-good 81 to see the cripples
Go limping home to Christendom on stilts.

BARABAS. Why, this is something: make account of me
As of thy fellow; we are villains both;
Both circumcised; we hate Christians both:
Be true and secret; thou shalt want no gold.
But stand aside; here comes Don Lodowick.

Enter LODOWICK. 82

LODOWICK. O, Barabas, well met;
Where is the diamond you told me of?

BARABAS. I have it for you, sir: please you walk in with me.—
What, ho, Abigail! open the door, I say!

Enter ABIGAIL, with letters.

ABIGAIL. In good time, father; here are letters come
]From Ormus, and the post stays here within.

BARABAS. Give me the letters.—Daughter, do you hear?
Entertain Lodowick, the governor's son,
With all the courtesy you can afford,
Provided that you keep your maidenhead:
Use him as if he were a Philistine;
Dissemble, swear, protest, vow love to him: 83
He is not of the seed of Abraham.—
[Aside to her.]
I am a little busy, sir; pray, pardon me.—
Abigail, bid him welcome for my sake.

ABIGAIL. For your sake and his own he's welcome hither.

BARABAS. Daughter, a word more: kiss him, speak him fair,
And like a cunning Jew so cast about,
That ye be both made sure 84 ere you come out.
[Aside to her.]

ABIGAIL. O father, Don Mathias is my love!

BARABAS. I know it: yet, I say, make love to him;
Do, it is requisite it should be so.—
[Aside to her.]
Nay, on my life, it is my factor's hand;
But go you in, I'll think upon the account.
[Exeunt ABIGAIL and LODOWICK into the house.]
The account is made, for Lodovico 85 dies.
My factor sends me word a merchant's fled
That owes me for a hundred tun of wine:
I weigh it thus much[snapping his fingers]! I have wealth enough;
For now by this has he kiss'd Abigail,
And she vows love to him, and he to her.
As sure as heaven rain'd manna for the Jews,
So sure shall he and Don Mathias die:
His father was my chiefest enemy.
生成:
Hwæt! Heofonrices weard, heark ye now to þis tale of treachery and woe,
Of Barabas þe Jew and his fell machinations 'gainst friend and foe.

In Maltaburg, where merchants ply þeir trade and ships do sail,
A drama most foul unfolds, a truly wretched tale.

Mathias, noble youth, his heart with love aflame,
Suspects þat 'twixt þe Jew and Lodowick þere lies some secret game.
His moðor Katharine, with venom in her breast,
Speaks ill of Jews, her hatred manifest.

Lo! Barabas, þe cunning Jew, his mind with malice fraught,
Seeks vengeance 'gainst þe governor, his son in schemes ycaught.
To Lodowick he speaks with honeyed words and sly,
"Of Abigail, my dohtor fair, to Mathias speak not nigh."

Þen comþ Katharine, her tongue with scorn ywhet,
But Barabas, with craft, her suspicions seeks to let.
Of trifles light he speaks, of matters of no weight,
While in his breast, dark plans do incubate.

Anon to Ithamore, his thrall most base and vile,
Barabas unveils his deeds with prideful smile:
"I've poisoned wells and brought men low with guile,
Left widows weeping, orphans in þe pile."

Ithamore, not to be outdone in wickedness,
Recounts his own misdeeds with gleeful stress:
"I've set fires and watched men burn alive,
And reveled in þeir pain, þeir futile strive."

But hark! Þe crux of Barabas's fell design,
To use his dohtor as a lure, a trap most fine.
Fair Abigail, whose heart for Mathias beats true,
Must feign affection for Lodowick, þe governor's son, anew.

"My dohtor," quoþ Barabas with voice of steel,
"Þou must to Lodowick þy love reveal.
Þough Mathias holds þy heart in thrall,
For vengeance sake, þou must obey my call."

Poor Abigail, torn 'twixt love and filial duty,
Must play þe part, despite her heart's true beauty.
With heavy heart and tear-stained cheek,
She nods assent, too crushed to speak.

Now Barabas, his plan in motion set,
Prepares to spring his trap, his vengeance debt.
Both Lodowick and Mathias shall fall,
Victims of his hatred, pawns in his grim caul.

O woeful day! O treachery most foul!
When love is twisted, made to serve þe owl
Of night, of darkness, and of bitter spite,
When fathers use þeir children in þeir fight.

Yet still þe tale unfolds, its end unknown,
As Barabas sows seeds of strife well-sown.
Will justice triumph? Will love prevail?
Or will dark vengeance rend þe fragile veil?

In Malta's streets, where merchants ply þeir trade,
A drama of þe soul is being played.
Of love and hate, of loyalty and betrayal,
Of human hearts in conflict's sore travail.

Mathias, noble youth, suspects not yet
Þe web of lies in which he's firmly set.
His love for Abigail, so pure and true,
Shall be his downfall, if Barabas's plans come through.

And Lodowick, þe governor's unwitting son,
Knows not þe danger he has stumbled on.
Barabas's honey-words have clouded clear his sight,
Leading him to peril in þe dark of night.

Katharine, with her hatred of þe Jews,
Unwittingly plays part in Barabas's ruse.
Her scorn and prejudice do blind her eyes
To þe real threat þat 'fore her lies.

Ithamore, þe servant base and cruel,
Finds in Barabas a kindred soul, a jewel
Of wickedness, a master of his art,
And gladly plays his own malevolent part.

But 'tis Abigail who bears þe heaviest load,
Forced by her faðer down a treacherous road.
Her heart for Mathias burns with love so bright,
Yet must she feign for Lodowick in þe night.

O cruel fate! O bitter twist of doom!
When children's hearts are sacrificed to gloom
Of parents' hate, when love is made a pawn
In games of vengeance, ere þe break of dawn.

Yet hope, þough faint, still flickers in þe dark,
For love, once kindled, leaves behind a mark
Þat neither hate nor fear can e'er erase,
A light þat shines beyond time and place.

Perchance fair Abigail, with courage bold,
Might yet break free from Barabas's hold.
Might yet find strength to choose þe path of right,
And lead both Mathias and Lodowick to light.

Or mayhap Mathias, with his noble heart,
Might see through Barabas's cunning art.
Might yet unravel all þe tangled skein,
And save both love and honor from dire stain.

E'en Lodowick, þough gulled by flattery's song,
Might wake to find þe truth, might right þe wrong.
For often 'tis þe ones we least expect
Who rise to greatness, all our doubts reject.

But soft! Þe outcome yet remains unknown,
Þe seeds of conflict have been barely sown.
We can but watch as þis fell drama plays,
And hope þat virtue triumphs o'er dark ways.

In Malta's streets, where ships at anchor ride,
Where merchants haggle and where fortunes bide,
A tale unfolds of love and hate entwined,
Of human hearts by passion underlined.

Of Barabas þe Jew, whose hatred burns so bright,
It threatens all to plunge in endless night.
Of Mathias and of Lodowick, rivals unwitting,
Pawns in a game beyond þeir own remitting.

Of Abigail, whose heart with love doth swell,
Yet must obey her faðer's dictates fell.
Of Ithamore, who revels in his master's schemes,
And Katharine, whose prejudice blinds her, it seems.

Þus stands þe tale, its end yet to unfold,
Of Malta's strife, of passions uncontrolled.
We watch and wait, with bated breath we stand,
To see if love or hate shall rule þis land.

O Fæder ure þu þe eart on heofonum,
Guide þese souls through þeir travails and woes.
May justice triumph, may true love prevail,
May light pierce through þis dark and bitter tale.

For in þe crucible of human strife,
Often 'tis þrough struggle we find life.
Þrough pain and loss, through betrayal's sting,
We learn þe truths þat make our spirits sing.

So let þis drama play, let fates unwind,
Let each character þeir true nature find.
For in þe end, 'tis not þe plot alone,
But how each soul to challenge has grown.

In Malta's streets, where þis tale doth unfold,
A mirror of our world, both new and old.
Of love and hate, of faith and foul betrayal,
Of human hearts in joy and bitter travail.

Þus ends our song, þough not þe tale entire,
Of Barabas þe Jew, his vengeance dire.
We leave þee now, O reader true and bold,
To ponder on þe truths þis tale has told.
summary:
Certainly! This passage from a theatrical play features several key characters and complex interactions:

1. **Mathias and Katharine** - Mathias suspects there is something secretive between the Jew, Barabas, and another character, Lodowick. Katharine, Mathias’s mother, expresses a negative opinion about Jews.

2. **Barabas and Lodowick** - Barabas wants to use Lodowick, the governor's son, as part of his plan for revenge against Mathias and the governor. He advises Lodowick to act innocuous in front of Mathias, specifically not to mention Abigail, Barabas's daughter.

3. **The conversation with Katharine** - Barabas distracts Katharine by talking about unrelated matters, hiding his true intentions.

4. **Barabas and Ithamore** - Barabas engages in a conversation with his servant Ithamore, revealing his malevolent deeds. Barabas recounts various villainous acts like poisoning wells, extortion, and leaving people destitute. Ithamore reciprocates, sharing his own misdeeds.

5. **Barabas's Plan** - The primary plot revolves around Barabas’s scheming. He instructs his daughter Abigail to feign affection towards Lodowick to facilitate his revenge plan, despite her true affection for Mathias. Barabas intends to betray both Lodowick and Mathias, culminating in their deaths as part of his vendetta against the governor.

6. **Abigail's Conflict** - Abigail is caught between her father's malevolent schemes and her genuine love for Mathias. Despite her reluctance, she is compelled to follow Barabas’s orders.

In summary, the passage is a complex interplay of deceit, manipulation, and plans for revenge orchestrated by Barabas, with his daughter Abigail and servant Ithamore playing crucial roles in his schemes against Mathias and the governor’s son, Lodowick.

I have it, sir, and 'tis at your command.

Thou hast thy crowns, fellow.—Come, let's away.

MATHIAS. Sirrah Jew, remember the book.

BARABAS. Marry, will I, sir.
[Exeunt KATHARlNE and MATHIAS.]

FIRST OFFICER. Come, I have made a reasonable market; let's away.
[Exeunt OFFICERS with SLAVES.]

BARABAS. Now let me know thy name, and therewithal
Thy birth, condition, and profession.

ITHAMORE. Faith, sir, my birth is but mean; my name's Ithamore;
my profession what you please.

BARABAS. Hast thou no trade? then listen to my words,
And I will teach [thee] that shall stick by thee:
First, be thou void of these affections,
Compassion, love, vain hope, and heartless fear;
Be mov'd at nothing, see thou pity none,
But to thyself smile when the Christians moan.

ITHAMORE. O, brave, master! 78 I worship your nose 79 for this.

BARABAS. As for myself, I walk abroad o' nights,
And kill sick people groaning under walls:
Sometimes I go about and poison wells;
And now and then, to cherish Christian thieves,
I am content to lose some of my crowns,
That I may, walking in my gallery,
See 'em go pinion'd along by my door.
Being young, I studied physic, and began
To practice first upon the Italian;
There I enrich'd the priests with burials,
And always kept the sexton's arms in ure 80
With digging graves and ringing dead men's knells:
And, after that, was I an engineer,
And in the wars 'twixt France and Germany,
Under pretence of helping Charles the Fifth,
Slew friend and enemy with my stratagems:
Then, after that, was I an usurer,
And with extorting, cozening, forfeiting,
And tricks belonging unto brokery,
I fill'd the gaols with bankrupts in a year,
And with young orphans planted hospitals;
And every moon made some or other mad,
And now and then one hang himself for grief,
Pinning upon his breast a long great scroll
How I with interest tormented him.
But mark how I am blest for plaguing them;—
I have as much coin as will buy the town.
But tell me now, how hast thou spent thy time?

ITHAMORE. Faith, master,
In setting Christian villages on fire,
Chaining of eunuchs, binding galley-slaves.
One time I was an hostler in an inn,
And in the night-time secretly would I steal
To travellers' chambers, and there cut their throats:
Once at Jerusalem, where the pilgrims kneel'd,
I strewed powder on the marble stones,
And therewithal their knees would rankle so,
That I have laugh'd a-good 81 to see the cripples
Go limping home to Christendom on stilts.

BARABAS. Why, this is something: make account of me
As of thy fellow; we are villains both;
Both circumcised; we hate Christians both:
Be true and secret; thou shalt want no gold.
But stand aside; here comes Don Lodowick.

Enter LODOWICK. 82

LODOWICK. O, Barabas, well met;
Where is the diamond you told me of?

BARABAS. I have it for you, sir: please you walk in with me.—
What, ho, Abigail! open the door, I say!

Enter ABIGAIL, with letters.

]From Ormus, and the post stays here within.

BARABAS. Give me the letters.—Daughter, do you hear?
Entertain Lodowick, the governor's son,
With all the courtesy you can afford,
Provided that you keep your maidenhead:
Use him as if he were a Philistine;
Dissemble, swear, protest, vow love to him: 83
He is not of the seed of Abraham.—
[Aside to her.]
I am a little busy, sir; pray, pardon me.—
Abigail, bid him welcome for my sake.

ABIGAIL. For your sake and his own he's welcome hither.

BARABAS. Daughter, a word more: kiss him, speak him fair,
And like a cunning Jew so cast about,
That ye be both made sure 84 ere you come out.
[Aside to her.]

ABIGAIL. O father, Don Mathias is my love!

BARABAS. I know it: yet, I say, make love to him;
Do, it is requisite it should be so.—
[Aside to her.]
Nay, on my life, it is my factor's hand;
But go you in, I'll think upon the account.
[Exeunt ABIGAIL and LODOWICK into the house.]
The account is made, for Lodovico 85 dies.
My factor sends me word a merchant's fled
That owes me for a hundred tun of wine:
I weigh it thus much[snapping his fingers]! I have wealth enough;
For now by this has he kiss'd Abigail,
And she vows love to him, and he to her.
As sure as heaven rain'd manna for the Jews,
So sure shall he and Don Mathias die:
His father was my chiefest enemy.
summary:
Certainly! This passage from a theatrical play features several key characters and complex interactions:

1. **Mathias and Katharine** - Mathias suspects there is something secretive between the Jew, Barabas, and another character, Lodowick. Katharine, Mathias’s mother, expresses a negative opinion about Jews.

2. **Barabas and Lodowick** - Barabas wants to use Lodowick, the governor's son, as part of his plan for revenge against Mathias and the governor. He advises Lodowick to act innocuous in front of Mathias, specifically not to mention Abigail, Barabas's daughter.

3. **The conversation with Katharine** - Barabas distracts Katharine by talking about unrelated matters, hiding his true intentions.

4. **Barabas and Ithamore** - Barabas engages in a conversation with his servant Ithamore, revealing his malevolent deeds. Barabas recounts various villainous acts like poisoning wells, extortion, and leaving people destitute. Ithamore reciprocates, sharing his own misdeeds.

5. **Barabas's Plan** - The primary plot revolves around Barabas’s scheming. He instructs his daughter Abigail to feign affection towards Lodowick to facilitate his revenge plan, despite her true affection for Mathias. Barabas intends to betray both Lodowick and Mathias, culminating in their deaths as part of his vendetta against the governor.

6. **Abigail's Conflict** - Abigail is caught between her father's malevolent schemes and her genuine love for Mathias. Despite her reluctance, she is compelled to follow Barabas’s orders.

In summary, the passage is a complex interplay of deceit, manipulation, and plans for revenge orchestrated by Barabas, with his daughter Abigail and servant Ithamore playing crucial roles in his schemes against Mathias and the governor’s son, Lodowick.

MATHIAS. What make the Jew and Lodowick so private?
I fear me 'tis about fair Abigail.
[Aside.]

BARABAS. [to LODOWICK.] Yonder comes Don Mathias; let us stay: 76
He loves my daughter, and she holds him dear;
But I have sworn to frustrate both their hopes,
And be reveng'd upon the—governor.
[Aside.]
[Exit LODOWICK.]

KATHARINE. This Moor is comeliest, is he not? speak, son.

MATHIAS. No, this is the better, mother, view this well.

BARABAS. Seem not to know me here before your mother,
Lest she mistrust the match that is in hand:
When you have brought her home, come to my house;
Think of me as thy father: son, farewell.

MATHIAS. But wherefore talk'd Don Lodowick with you?

BARABAS. Tush, man! we talk'd of diamonds, not of Abigail.

KATHARINE. Tell me, Mathias, is not that the Jew?

BARABAS. As for the comment on the Maccabees,
I have it, sir, and 'tis at your command.

MATHIAS. Yes, madam, and my talk with him was 77
About the borrowing of a book or two.

KATHARINE. Converse not with him; he is cast off from heaven.—
Thou hast thy crowns, fellow.—Come, let's away.

MATHIAS. Sirrah Jew, remember the book.

BARABAS. Marry, will I, sir.

原文:
[TAMBURLAINE gets up on him into his chair.]

TAMBURLAINE. Now clear the triple region of the air,
And let the Majesty of Heaven behold
Their scourge and terror tread on emperors.
Smile, stars that reign'd at my nativity,
And dim the brightness of your 199 neighbour lamps;
Disdain to borrow light of Cynthia!
For I, the chiefest lamp of all the earth,
First rising in the east with mild aspect,
But fixed now in the meridian line,
Will send up fire to your turning spheres,
And cause the sun to borrow light of you.
My sword struck fire from his coat of steel,
Even in Bithynia, when I took this Turk;
As when a fiery exhalation,
Wrapt in the bowels of a freezing cloud,
Fighting for passage, make[s] the welkin crack,
And casts a flash of lightning to 200 the earth:
But, ere I march to wealthy Persia,
Or leave Damascus and th' Egyptian fields,
As was the fame of Clymene's brain-sick son
That almost brent 201 the axle-tree of heaven,
So shall our swords, our lances, and our shot
Fill all the air with fiery meteors;
Then, when the sky shall wax as red as blood,
It shall be said I made it red myself,
To make me think of naught but blood and war.

ZABINA. Unworthy king, that by thy cruelty
Unlawfully usurp'st the Persian seat,
Dar'st thou, that never saw an emperor
Before thou met my husband in the field,
Being thy captive, thus abuse his state,
Keeping his kingly body in a cage,
That roofs of gold and sun-bright palaces
Should have prepar'd to entertain his grace?
And treading him beneath thy loathsome feet,
Whose feet the kings 202 of Africa have kiss'd?

TECHELLES. You must devise some torment worse, my lord,
To make these captives rein their lavish tongues.

TAMBURLAINE. Zenocrate, look better to your slave.

ZENOCRATE. She is my handmaid's slave, and she shall look
That these abuses flow not from 203 her tongue.—
Chide her, Anippe.

ANIPPE. Let these be warnings, then, for you, 204 my slave,
How you abuse the person of the king;
Or else I swear to have you whipt stark nak'd. 205

BAJAZETH. Great Tamburlaine, great in my overthrow,
Ambitious pride shall make thee fall as low,
For treading on the back of Bajazeth,
That should be horsed on four mighty kings.

TAMBURLAINE. Thy names, and titles, and thy dignities 206
Are fled from Bajazeth, and remain with me,
That will maintain it 'gainst a world of kings.—
Put him in again.

[They put him into the cage.]

BAJAZETH. Is this a place for mighty Bajazeth?
Confusion light on him that helps thee thus!

TAMBURLAINE. There, whiles 207 he lives, shall Bajazeth be kept;
And, where I go, be thus in triumph drawn;
And thou, his wife, shalt 208 feed him with the scraps
My servitors shall bring thee from my board;
For he that gives him other food than this,
Shall sit by him, and starve to death himself:
This is my mind, and I will have it so.
Not all the kings and emperors of the earth,
If they would lay their crowne before my feet,
Shall ransom him, or take him from his cage:
The ages that shall talk of Tamburlaine,
Even from this day to Plato's wondrous year,
Shall talk how I have handled Bajazeth:
These Moors, that drew him from Bithynia
To fair Damascus, where we now remain,
Shall lead him with us wheresoe'er we go.—
Techelles, and my loving followers,
Now may we see Damascus' lofty towers,
Like to the shadows of Pyramides
That with their beauties grace 209 the Memphian fields.
The golden stature 210 of their feather'd bird, 211
That spreads her wings upon the city-walls,
Shall not defend it from our battering shot:
The townsmen mask in silk and cloth of gold,
And every house is as a treasury;
The men, the treasure, and the town are 212 ours.

THERIDAMAS. Your tents of white now pitch'd before the gates,
And gentle flags of amity display'd,
I doubt not but the governor will yield,
Offering Damascus to your majesty.

TAMBURLAINE. So shall he have his life, and all the rest:
But, if he stay until the bloody flag
Be once advanc'd on my vermilion tent,
He dies, and those that kept us out so long;
And, when they see me march in black array,
With mournful streamers hanging down their heads,
Were in that city all the world contain'd,
Not one should scape, but perish by our swords.

ZENOCRATE. Yet would you have some pity for my sake,
Because it is my country 213 and my father's.

TAMBURLAINE. Not for the world, Zenocrate, if I have sworn.—
Come; bring in the Turk.
生成:
Forsooth, I shall endeavour to craft a passage in the manner of Old English, though it be not the true tongue of Beowulf and the Anglo-Saxons, but rather a more accessible form akin to that of Chaucer or the early modern English of Marlowe's time. Here follows my attempt:

Lo, in the great hall of conquest, where banners of vanquished foes did hang,
Tamburlaine, that scourge of God, did mount his throne of gold and bone.
His eyes, like unto burning coals, surveyed the cowering throng,
And from his lips did issue forth a speech to shake the very stone:

"Hark ye, emperors and kings, ye trembling lords of earth!
Behold Tamburlaine, whose name doth strike fear in mortal hearts.
From humble shepherd's cot to this exalted birth,
My sword hath carved an empire, my will hath sundered realms apart.

As heaven's orbs do move in their appointed spheres,
So doth my power ascend, unstoppable and vast.
Bajazeth, once proud emperor, now grovels at my feet in tears,
His crown and sceptre mine, his glories now surpassed.

Let all who hear my name bow down in dread and awe,
For I am he who makes the world his throne.
No mortal force can stay my hand or flout my law,
My will be done on earth, as 'tis in heaven's dome."

But lo, from 'midst the throng, a woman's voice did rise,
'Twas Zabina, wife of Bajazeth, her eyes aflame with rage:
"Thou cur! Thou base-born churl! Thy words are naught but lies!
How dar'st thou sit upon the throne of Persia's heritage?

My lord, my Bajazeth, a king of noble line,
Now languishes in chains, like beast in iron cage.
O cruel fate! O bitter cup! That we should thus decline,
While this upstart doth strut and preen upon the stage!"

Then Techelles, loyal to his lord, did step forth bold,
His hand upon his sword, his visage grim and stern:
"My liege, shall we not silence these tongues so overbold?
Methinks a harsher torment they have yet to learn."

But ere the blade could fall, fair Zenocrate did speak,
Her voice a gentle breeze amidst the storm of wrath:
"Anippe, good my maid, rebuke yon shrew so meek,
Lest harsher punishments be meted on her path."

From out his cage of iron, Bajazeth's voice did sound,
A roar of defiance, though his body lay in chains:
"Tamburlaine! Thou peacock! Pride shall bring thee to the ground!
The higher thou dost climb, the harder fall remains!"

With scorn upon his lips, Tamburlaine did turn his gaze,
Upon the fallen emperor, once so proud and high:
"Thy titles and thy claims are but an empty phrase,
Thy glories now are mine, thy name shall fade and die.

In cage thou shalt remain, on scraps and offal fed,
And he who disobeys shall know the pangs of thirst.
No power on this earth shall lift thy fallen head,
For future ages shall remember me the first!"

Then Theridamas, bold captain of the conquering host,
Did speak of battles won and cities yet to fall:
"My lord, our armies stand at Damascus' gates to boast,
Perchance the governor will yield to mercy's call?"

But Zenocrate, with heart so torn 'twixt love and land,
Did plead for clemency with words both soft and sweet:
"My lord Tamburlaine, I beg thee stay thy mighty hand,
For Damascus is my home, where first I learned to greet."

Yet Tamburlaine, unmoved by love or pity's plea,
Did shake his head, his face as stone, his heart as steel:
"My oath is sworn, my word is bond, it must needs be,
That Damascus falls, lest all my conquests prove unreal."

And so the scene was set, the players in their place,
A tableau of ambition, love, and cruel design.
Tamburlaine astride the world, his foes in dire disgrace,
While Fate looked on and pondered what the stars might yet divine.

Oh, what a tale of power and pride here doth unfold!
Of empires won and lost, of crowns cast in the dust.
How fleeting is the glory that mortals seek to hold,
How vain the earthly treasures in which they place their trust!

Yet still the wheels of fortune turn, the ages pass away,
And men still dream of conquest, of realms beyond the sea.
But let them heed the lesson of Tamburlaine's brief day,
For pride goeth before destruction, as it was and e'er shall be.

So ends this tale of Tamburlaine, that scourge of God so bold,
Whose deeds still echo down the corridors of time.
A warning and a wonder, in annals yet untold,
Of how ambition's fire can make a man sublime.

But mark ye well, dear reader, and ponder on this thought:
Though men may strive for greatness and seek to touch the sky,
All earthly pomp and glory shall one day come to naught,
For dust we are, and unto dust we all return to lie.
summary:
Certainly! This passage is an excerpt from Christopher Marlowe's play "Tamburlaine." Here's a summary of its main content:

**Scene Description**:
- **Tamburlaine** asserts his dominance by ascending to a throne or prominent position.

**Key Events**:
- **Tamburlaine** gives a soliloquy where he boasts about his power and the fear he instills in emperors. He describes how he has subjugated his enemies, including Bajazeth, and how his ascent to power is as monumental as heavenly events.
- **Zabina**, Bajazeth's wife, condemns Tamburlaine's cruelty and his unlawful seizure of the Persian throne. She laments her husband’s captivity, who she believes deserves respect and honor rather than imprisonment in a cage.
- **Techelles**, one of Tamburlaine’s followers, suggests that more severe torment should be devised for the captives to silence their complaints.
- **Zenocrate**, Tamburlaine's love interest, instructs her handmaid **Anippe** to reprimand Zabina for her insults.
- **Bajazeth** speaks from his confinement, cursing Tamburlaine and warning that his pride will lead to his downfall.
- **Tamburlaine** dismisses Bajazeth’s titles and claims, declaring that Bajazeth’s former glories now belong to him. He orders that Bajazeth be kept in the cage and fed scraps, asserting that anyone who disobeys will starve.
- He further declares that no power on earth will be able to rescue Bajazeth from his captivity, ensuring that future generations will remember his deeds.
- **Theridamas** talks about how Tamburlaine’s forces are ready to capture Damascus, anticipating that the governor might surrender to avoid bloodshed.
- **Zenocrate** appeals to Tamburlaine to have pity on Damascus, her homeland, but Tamburlaine remains resolute and declares that he must keep his oath.

**Themes**:
- The passage vividly explores themes of power, cruelty, pride, and conquest.
- Tamburlaine’s monologue emphasizes his belief in his own greatness and invincibility.
- Zabina’s and Bajazeth’s speeches underscore the suffering caused by Tamburlaine’s ambition, as well as the fall from high status to utter humiliation.
- Zenocrate’s plea highlights the personal conflicts and emotional costs of war and conquest.

Overall, the passage illustrates Tamburlaine’s ruthless nature, his disregard for mercy, and his desire to be eternally remembered for his conquests.
