It will not be a satisfactory answer to say, that a person, who does not assent to a proposition you advance; after having conceived the object in the same manner with you; immediately conceives it in a different manner, and has different ideas of it. This answer is unsatisfactory; not because it contains any falshood, but because it discovers not all the truth. It is contest, that in all cases, wherein we dissent from any person, we conceive both sides of the question; but as we can believe only one, it evidently follows, that the belief must make some difference betwixt that conception to which we assent, and that from which we dissent. We may mingle, and unite, and separate, and confound, and vary our ideas in a hundred different ways; but until there appears some principle, which fixes one of these different situations, we have in reality no opinion: And this principle, as it plainly makes no addition to our precedent ideas, can only change the manner of our conceiving them.

The difference between belief and disbelief is not in the ideas themselves but in the manner of conceiving them.

The author uses examples to illustrate that disbelief does not imply a lack of understanding or the inability to conceive the ideas in question. 原文:
There is, in Dr. Tillotson's writings, an argument against the real presence, which is as concise, and elegant, and strong as any argument can possibly be supposed against a doctrine, so little worthy of a serious refutation. It is acknowledged on all hands, says that learned prelate, that the authority, either of the scripture or of tradition, is founded merely in the testimony of the apostles, who were eye-witnesses to those miracles of our Saviour, by which he proved his divine mission. Our evidence, then, for the truth of the Christian religion is less than the evidence for the truth of our senses; because, even in the first authors of our religion, it was no greater; and it is evident it must diminish in passing from them to their disciples; nor can any one rest such confidence in their testimony, as in the immediate object of his senses. But a weaker evidence can never destroy a stronger; and therefore, were the doctrine of the real presence ever so clearly revealed in scripture, it were directly contrary to the rules of just reasoning to give our assent to it. It contradicts sense, though both the scripture and tradition, on which it is supposed to be built, carry not such evidence with them as sense; when they are considered merely as external evidences, and are not brought home to every one's breast, by the immediate operation of the Holy Spirit.
Nothing is so convenient as a decisive argument of this kind, which must at least silence the most arrogant bigotry and superstition, and free us from their impertinent solicitations. I flatter myself, that I have discovered an argument of a like nature, which, if just, will, with the wise and learned, be an everlasting check to all kinds of superstitious delusion, and consequently, will be useful as long as the world endures. For so long, I presume, will the accounts of miracles and prodigies be found in all history, sacred and profane.
87.Though experience be our only guide in reasoning concerning matters of fact; it must be acknowledged, that this guide is not altogether infallible, but in some cases is apt to lead us into errors. One, who in our climate, should expect better weather in any week of June than in one of December, would reason justly, and conformably to experience; but it is certain, that he may happen, in the event, to find himself mistaken. However, we may observe, that, in such a case, he would have no cause to complain of experience; because it commonly informs us beforehand of the uncertainty, by that contrariety of events, which we may learn from a diligent observation. All effects follow not with like certainty from their supposed causes. Some events are found, in all countries and all ages, to have been constantly conjoined together: Others are found to have been more variable, and sometimes to disappoint our expectations; so that, in our reasonings concerning matter of fact, there are all imaginable degrees of assurance, from the highest certainty to the lowest species of moral evidence.
A wise man, therefore, proportions his belief to the evidence. In such conclusions as are founded on an infallible experience, he expects the event with the last degree of assurance, and regards his past experience as a full proof of the future existence of that event. In other cases, he proceeds with more caution: He weighs the opposite experiments: He considers which side is supported by the greater number of experiments: to that side he inclines, with doubt and hesitation; and when at last he fixes his judgement, the evidence exceeds not what we properly call probability. All probability, then, supposes an opposition of experiments and observations, where the one side is found to overbalance the other, and to produce a degree of evidence, proportioned to the superiority. A hundred instances or experiments on one side, and fifty on another, afford a doubtful expectation of any event; though a hundred uniform experiments, with only one that is contradictory, reasonably beget a pretty strong degree of assurance. In all cases, we must balance the opposite experiments, where they are opposite, and deduct the smaller number from the greater, in order to know the exact force of the superior evidence.
88.To apply these principles to a particular instance; we may observe, that there is no species of reasoning more common, more useful, and even necessary to human life, than that which is derived from the testimony of men, and the reports of eye-witnesses and spectators. This species of reasoning, perhaps, one may deny to be founded on the relation of cause and effect. I shall not dispute about a word. It will be sufficient to observe that our assurance in any argument of this kind is derived from no other principle than our observation of the veracity of human testimony, and of the usual conformity of facts to the reports of witnesses. It being a general maxim, that no objects have any discoverable connexion together, and that all the inferences, which we can draw from one to another, are founded merely on our experience of their constant and regular conjunction; it is evident, that we ought not to make an exception to this maxim in favour of human testimony, whose connexion with any event seems, in itself, as little necessary as any other. Were not the memory tenacious to a certain degree, had not men commonly an inclination to truth and a principle of probity; were they not sensible to shame, when detected in a falsehood: Were not these, I say, discovered by experience to be qualities, inherent in human nature, we should never repose the least confidence in human testimony. A man delirious, or noted for falsehood and villany, has no manner of authority with us.
And as the evidence, derived from witnesses and human testimony, is founded on past experience, so it varies with the experience, and is regarded either as a proof or a probability, according as the conjunction between any particular kind of report and any kind of object has been found to be constant or variable. There are a number of circumstances to be taken into consideration in all judgements of this kind; and the ultimate standard, by which we determine all disputes, that may arise concerning them, is always derived from experience and observation. Where this experience is not entirely uniform on any side, it is attended with an unavoidable contrariety in our judgements, and with the same opposition and mutual destruction of argument as in every other kind of evidence. We frequently hesitate concerning the reports of others. We balance the opposite circumstances, which cause any doubt or uncertainty; and when we discover a superiority on any side, we incline to it; but still with a diminution of assurance, in proportion to the force of its antagonist.
89.This contrariety of evidence, in the present case, may be derived from several different causes; from the opposition of contrary testimony; from the character or number of the witnesses; from the manner of their delivering their testimony; or from the union of all these circumstances. We entertain a suspicion concerning any matter of fact, when the witnesses contradict each other; when they are but few, or of a doubtful character; when they have an interest in what they affirm; when they deliver their testimony with hesitation, or on the contrary, with too violent asseverations. There are many other particulars of the same kind, which may diminish or destroy the force of any argument, derived from human testimony.
Suppose, for instance, that the fact, which the testimony endeavours to establish, partakes of the extraordinary and the marvellous; in that case, the evidence, resulting from the testimony, admits of a diminution, greater or less, in proportion as the fact is more or less unusual. The reason why we place any credit in witnesses and historians, is not derived from any connexion, which we perceive a priori, between testimony and reality, but because we are accustomed to find a conformity between them. But when the fact attested is such a one as has seldom fallen under our observation, here is a contest of two opposite experiences; of which the one destroys the other, as far as its force goes, and the superior can only operate on the mind by the force, which remains. The very same principle of experience, which gives us a certain degree of assurance in the testimony of witnesses, gives us also, in this case, another degree of assurance against the fact, which they endeavour to establish; from which contradition there necessarily arises a counterpoize, and mutual destruction of belief and authority.
生成:
As philosophers, we are compelled to examine the foundations of our beliefs and the methods by which we arrive at them. In this exploration, we shall delve into the intricate relationship between evidence, testimony, and belief formation, with particular attention to the realm of religious and miraculous claims. Our inquiry will draw inspiration from Dr. Tillotson's argument against the real presence of Christ in the Eucharist, and expand upon this to consider the broader implications for human testimony and reasoning.

Let us begin by acknowledging that experience serves as our primary guide in reasoning about facts. As we navigate the world, we accumulate a vast repository of observations and interactions that shape our understanding of reality. This experiential knowledge forms the bedrock upon which we construct our beliefs and make judgments about new information. However, it is crucial to recognize that experience, while invaluable, is not infallible. Our perceptions can be deceived, our memories can be fallible, and our interpretations can be biased. Thus, while we rely heavily on experience, we must approach it with a measure of humility and skepticism.

This brings us to a fundamental principle of epistemology: a wise person should proportion their belief to the strength of evidence. This maxim, often attributed to David Hume, encapsulates the essence of rational inquiry. It suggests that our confidence in any proposition should be commensurate with the quality and quantity of evidence supporting it. This principle serves as a safeguard against both gullibility and excessive skepticism, encouraging a balanced approach to knowledge acquisition.

When we turn our attention to human testimony, we find ourselves in a complex terrain. On one hand, testimony is a crucial source of information about the world beyond our immediate experience. We rely on the reports of others to learn about history, distant places, and events we did not personally witness. On the other hand, testimony is inherently secondary evidence, filtered through the perceptions, memory, and potential biases of the witness.

The general reliability of human testimony can be attributed to observed regularities in truth-telling and memory. In our daily lives, we find that most people, most of the time, report events with reasonable accuracy. This regularity forms the basis of our trust in testimony. However, the strength of testimony varies considerably based on circumstances. Factors such as the complexity of the event being reported, the time elapsed since its occurrence, and the emotional state of the witness can all affect the reliability of the account.

When we encounter extraordinary claims, such as reports of miraculous events, we must apply heightened scrutiny. These claims, by their very nature, conflict with our usual experiences and understanding of natural laws. As such, they require stronger evidence to overcome the inherent improbability of their occurrence. This principle is often expressed in the adage attributed to Carl Sagan: "Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence."

The credibility of testimony is not solely determined by the content of the claim, but also by various attributes of the witness and the manner of testimony. The character of the witness plays a crucial role; a history of honesty and accuracy lends greater weight to their testimony. The number of witnesses can also be significant; multiple independent accounts corroborating the same event generally strengthen the overall credibility of the claim. Additionally, the manner in which the testimony is delivered – whether it is consistent, detailed, and coherent – can affect its persuasiveness.

When testimony reports extraordinary events, we often find ourselves in a situation where there is a conflict of experiences. On one side, we have the testimony itself, which if true, would constitute a new experience contradicting our prior understanding. On the other side, we have our accumulated experience of how the world typically operates. This conflict leads to a mutual weakening of belief. The extraordinary nature of the claim reduces our confidence in the testimony, while the existence of the testimony challenges our confidence in our understanding of natural laws.

To illustrate these principles, let us return to Dr. Tillotson's argument against the real presence of Christ in the Eucharist. This doctrine, central to many Christian denominations, claims that the bread and wine of the Eucharist literally transform into the body and blood of Christ. Tillotson argued that the evidence for this belief, based on the testimonies of the apostles and church tradition, is weaker than the direct sensory evidence we have of the bread and wine remaining unchanged.

This argument exemplifies the tension between testimony and direct experience. The doctrine of transubstantiation asks us to believe that something extraordinary occurs – a physical transformation that contradicts our sensory experience. The evidence for this claim rests primarily on testimony, passed down through generations of religious tradition. However, our direct sensory experience tells us that the bread and wine remain unchanged in their physical properties.

Applying our principle of proportioning belief to evidence, we must weigh these competing claims. On one hand, we have the testimony of religious authorities and the weight of tradition. On the other, we have our immediate sensory experience and our understanding of physical laws. The extraordinary nature of the claim – that substances can change their essential nature while retaining all observable properties – demands correspondingly strong evidence.

This example illustrates a broader challenge in evaluating religious and miraculous claims. Such claims often rely heavily on testimony, sometimes separated from the original events by considerable time and cultural distance. They frequently describe events that, if true, would fundamentally alter our understanding of reality. As such, they present a particular challenge to our principle of proportioning belief to evidence.

However, it is crucial to note that this skeptical approach does not necessarily negate the possibility of religious belief or the occurrence of extraordinary events. Rather, it suggests that such beliefs should be held with a degree of epistemic humility, acknowledging the limitations of the available evidence. It also encourages a more nuanced understanding of faith, one that perhaps emphasizes personal experience and moral conviction over claims of historical or physical fact.

Extending this principle to human testimony as a whole, we can see that our confidence in any testimony is indeed based on our past experience with the veracity of human reports. We have learned through experience that human testimony is generally reliable in everyday matters, but becomes less reliable when reporting complex, emotionally charged, or distant events. We have also learned to be more skeptical of claims that contradict our understanding of how the world works.

This understanding allows us to navigate the vast sea of information and claims we encounter daily. We can tentatively accept routine claims without demanding extensive evidence, while reserving judgment on more extraordinary claims until stronger evidence is presented. This approach allows us to function effectively in a world where we cannot personally verify every piece of information we receive, while still maintaining a rational skepticism towards dubious claims.

However, this principle also presents challenges. It requires us to constantly evaluate the strength of evidence and adjust our beliefs accordingly. It demands that we be willing to change our minds when presented with new evidence, even if that evidence contradicts long-held beliefs. This can be psychologically difficult, as humans tend to seek confirmation of their existing beliefs rather than actively challenging them.

Moreover, the principle of proportioning belief to evidence can lead to disagreements when different individuals assess the same evidence differently. What constitutes "strong" evidence can vary based on one's background knowledge, personal experiences, and epistemological assumptions. This can lead to situations where rational individuals, applying the same principle, arrive at different conclusions.

Another challenge arises when we consider the cumulative effect of multiple pieces of weak evidence. While any single piece of testimony about an extraordinary event might be insufficient to warrant belief, how should we evaluate a large body of such testimony accumulated over time? This question becomes particularly relevant when considering historical religious claims or reports of paranormal phenomena.

Furthermore, we must consider the potential consequences of belief or disbelief. In some cases, the stakes of a belief may be high, either in terms of personal consequences or broader societal impacts. How should these potential consequences factor into our assessment of evidence and formation of beliefs? This question touches on the interface between epistemology and ethics, raising complex issues about the relationship between truth and utility.

As we navigate these challenges, it becomes clear that the process of belief formation and evidence evaluation is not a simple, mechanical procedure, but a nuanced and context-dependent endeavor. It requires not only logical reasoning and empirical observation, but also an understanding of human psychology, the nature of probability, and the complexities of human communication.

In conclusion, our exploration of evidence, testimony, and belief formation reveals a complex landscape of epistemological challenges. The principle of proportioning belief to evidence serves as a valuable guide, encouraging rational inquiry and skepticism towards extraordinary claims. However, its application requires careful consideration of the nature of evidence, the reliability of testimony, and the inherent probabilities of different claims.

As philosophers, our task is not merely to apply these principles rigidly, but to continually refine our understanding of how knowledge is acquired and justified. We must remain open to new evidence and arguments, while maintaining a critical stance towards all claims, including our own beliefs. In doing so, we can hope to approach a more accurate understanding of reality, while acknowledging the inherent limitations of human knowledge.

Ultimately, this approach to evidence and belief encourages intellectual humility – a recognition that our beliefs are provisional, subject to revision in light of new evidence. It fosters a spirit of inquiry, urging us to actively seek out evidence that might challenge our existing beliefs. And it promotes a form of intellectual honesty, asking us to openly acknowledge the strengths and weaknesses of the evidence supporting our beliefs.

In a world increasingly polarized by competing claims and ideologies, this epistemological framework offers a path towards more reasoned discourse and belief formation. By grounding our beliefs in proportional evidence and maintaining a willingness to revise them, we can hope to navigate the complexities of human knowledge with greater wisdom and accuracy.
summary:
The passage discusses the reliability of evidence and testimony in reasoning, particularly in matters relating to religion and miraculous claims. The author references Dr. Tillotson's argument against the real presence of Christ in the Eucharist, highlighting that the evidence for religious beliefs, based on apostles' testimonies, is weaker than direct sensory evidence. The author then generalizes this principle to human testimony as a whole, arguing that our confidence in any testimony is based on our past experience with the veracity of human reports.

Key points include:
1. Experience is our primary guide in reasoning about facts, though it is not infallible.
2. A wise person should proportion their belief to the strength of evidence.
3. Human testimony is generally reliable because of observed regularities in truth-telling and memory but varies in strength based on circumstances.
4. Extraordinary claims (e.g., miracles) require stronger evidence, as they conflict with our usual experiences.
5. The credibility of testimony is affected by witness character, number, and the manner of testimony.
6. When testimony reports extraordinary events, there is a conflict of experiences, leading to a mutual weakening of belief.

Overall, the passage emphasizes that belief should be grounded in proportional evidence and that extraordinary claims require extraordinarily strong evidence due to their inherent improbability.

There are many other particulars of the same kind, which may diminish or destroy the force of any argument, derived from human testimony.
Suppose, for instance, that the fact, which the testimony endeavours to establish, partakes of the extraordinary and the marvellous; in that case, the evidence, resulting from the testimony, admits of a diminution, greater or less, in proportion as the fact is more or less unusual. The reason why we place any credit in witnesses and historians, is not derived from any connexion, which we perceive a priori, between testimony and reality, but because we are accustomed to find a conformity between them. But when the fact attested is such a one as has seldom fallen under our observation, here is a contest of two opposite experiences; of which the one destroys the other, as far as its force goes, and the superior can only operate on the mind by the force, which remains. The very same principle of experience, which gives us a certain degree of assurance in the testimony of witnesses, gives us also, in this case, another degree of assurance against the fact, which they endeavour to establish; from which contradition there necessarily arises a counterpoize, and mutual destruction of belief and authority.
summary:
The passage discusses the reliability of evidence and testimony in reasoning, particularly in matters relating to religion and miraculous claims. The author references Dr. Tillotson's argument against the real presence of Christ in the Eucharist, highlighting that the evidence for religious beliefs, based on apostles' testimonies, is weaker than direct sensory evidence. The author then generalizes this principle to human testimony as a whole, arguing that our confidence in any testimony is based on our past experience with the veracity of human reports.

Key points include:
1. Experience is our primary guide in reasoning about facts, though it is not infallible.
2. A wise person should proportion their belief to the strength of evidence.
3. Human testimony is generally reliable because of observed regularities in truth-telling and memory but varies in strength based on circumstances.
4. Extraordinary claims (e.g., miracles) require stronger evidence, as they conflict with our usual experiences.
5. The credibility of testimony is affected by witness character, number, and the manner of testimony.
6. When testimony reports extraordinary events, there is a conflict of experiences, leading to a mutual weakening of belief.

Overall, the passage emphasizes that belief should be grounded in proportional evidence and that extraordinary claims require extraordinarily strong evidence due to their inherent improbability.

原文:
There is, in Dr. Tillotson's writings, an argument against the real presence, which is as concise, and elegant, and strong as any argument can possibly be supposed against a doctrine, so little worthy of a serious refutation. It is acknowledged on all hands, says that learned prelate, that the authority, either of the scripture or of tradition, is founded merely in the testimony of the apostles, who were eye-witnesses to those miracles of our Saviour, by which he proved his divine mission. Our evidence, then, for the truth of the Christian religion is less than the evidence for the truth of our senses; because, even in the first authors of our religion, it was no greater; and it is evident it must diminish in passing from them to their disciples; nor can any one rest such confidence in their testimony, as in the immediate object of his senses. But a weaker evidence can never destroy a stronger; and therefore, were the doctrine of the real presence ever so clearly revealed in scripture, it were directly contrary to the rules of just reasoning to give our assent to it. It contradicts sense, though both the scripture and tradition, on which it is supposed to be built, carry not such evidence with them as sense; when they are considered merely as external evidences, and are not brought home to every one's breast, by the immediate operation of the Holy Spirit.
Nothing is so convenient as a decisive argument of this kind, which must at least silence the most arrogant bigotry and superstition, and free us from their impertinent solicitations. I flatter myself, that I have discovered an argument of a like nature, which, if just, will, with the wise and learned, be an everlasting check to all kinds of superstitious delusion, and consequently, will be useful as long as the world endures. For so long, I presume, will the accounts of miracles and prodigies be found in all history, sacred and profane.
87.Though experience be our only guide in reasoning concerning matters of fact; it must be acknowledged, that this guide is not altogether infallible, but in some cases is apt to lead us into errors. One, who in our climate, should expect better weather in any week of June than in one of December, would reason justly, and conformably to experience; but it is certain, that he may happen, in the event, to find himself mistaken. However, we may observe, that, in such a case, he would have no cause to complain of experience; because it commonly informs us beforehand of the uncertainty, by that contrariety of events, which we may learn from a diligent observation. All effects follow not with like certainty from their supposed causes. Some events are found, in all countries and all ages, to have been constantly conjoined together: Others are found to have been more variable, and sometimes to disappoint our expectations; so that, in our reasonings concerning matter of fact, there are all imaginable degrees of assurance, from the highest certainty to the lowest species of moral evidence.
A wise man, therefore, proportions his belief to the evidence. In such conclusions as are founded on an infallible experience, he expects the event with the last degree of assurance, and regards his past experience as a full proof of the future existence of that event. In other cases, he proceeds with more caution: He weighs the opposite experiments: He considers which side is supported by the greater number of experiments: to that side he inclines, with doubt and hesitation; and when at last he fixes his judgement, the evidence exceeds not what we properly call probability. All probability, then, supposes an opposition of experiments and observations, where the one side is found to overbalance the other, and to produce a degree of evidence, proportioned to the superiority. A hundred instances or experiments on one side, and fifty on another, afford a doubtful expectation of any event; though a hundred uniform experiments, with only one that is contradictory, reasonably beget a pretty strong degree of assurance. In all cases, we must balance the opposite experiments, where they are opposite, and deduct the smaller number from the greater, in order to know the exact force of the superior evidence.
88.To apply these principles to a particular instance; we may observe, that there is no species of reasoning more common, more useful, and even necessary to human life, than that which is derived from the testimony of men, and the reports of eye-witnesses and spectators. This species of reasoning, perhaps, one may deny to be founded on the relation of cause and effect. I shall not dispute about a word. It will be sufficient to observe that our assurance in any argument of this kind is derived from no other principle than our observation of the veracity of human testimony, and of the usual conformity of facts to the reports of witnesses. It being a general maxim, that no objects have any discoverable connexion together, and that all the inferences, which we can draw from one to another, are founded merely on our experience of their constant and regular conjunction; it is evident, that we ought not to make an exception to this maxim in favour of human testimony, whose connexion with any event seems, in itself, as little necessary as any other. Were not the memory tenacious to a certain degree, had not men commonly an inclination to truth and a principle of probity; were they not sensible to shame, when detected in a falsehood: Were not these, I say, discovered by experience to be qualities, inherent in human nature, we should never repose the least confidence in human testimony. A man delirious, or noted for falsehood and villany, has no manner of authority with us.
And as the evidence, derived from witnesses and human testimony, is founded on past experience, so it varies with the experience, and is regarded either as a proof or a probability, according as the conjunction between any particular kind of report and any kind of object has been found to be constant or variable. There are a number of circumstances to be taken into consideration in all judgements of this kind; and the ultimate standard, by which we determine all disputes, that may arise concerning them, is always derived from experience and observation. Where this experience is not entirely uniform on any side, it is attended with an unavoidable contrariety in our judgements, and with the same opposition and mutual destruction of argument as in every other kind of evidence. We frequently hesitate concerning the reports of others. We balance the opposite circumstances, which cause any doubt or uncertainty; and when we discover a superiority on any side, we incline to it; but still with a diminution of assurance, in proportion to the force of its antagonist.
91.This contrariety of evidence, in the present case, may be derived from several different causes; from the opposition of contrary testimony; from the character or number of the witnesses; from the manner of their delivering their testimony; or from the union of all these circumstances. We entertain a suspicion concerning any matter of fact, when the witnesses contradict each other; when they are but few, or of a doubtful character; when they have an interest in what they affirm; when they deliver their testimony with hesitation, or on the contrary, with too violent asseverations. There are many other particulars of the same kind, which may diminish or destroy the force of any argument, derived from human testimony.
Suppose, for instance, that the fact, which the testimony endeavours to establish, partakes of the extraordinary and the marvellous; in that case, the evidence, resulting from the testimony, admits of a diminution, greater or less, in proportion as the fact is more or less unusual. The reason why we place any credit in witnesses and historians, is not derived from any connexion, which we perceive a priori, between testimony and reality, but because we are accustomed to find a conformity between them. But when the fact attested is such a one as has seldom fallen under our observation, here is a contest of two opposite experiences; of which the one destroys the other, as far as its force goes, and the superior can only operate on the mind by the force, which remains. The very same principle of experience, which gives us a certain degree of assurance in the testimony of witnesses, gives us also, in this case, another degree of assurance against the fact, which they endeavour to establish; from which contradition there necessarily arises a counterpoize, and mutual destruction of belief and authority.

原文:
It will be best to prepare the ground for my thesis by a few very general remarks on the method of getting at scientific truth. It is a common platitude that a complete acquaintance with any one thing, however small, would require a knowledge of the entire universe. Not a sparrow falls to the ground but some of the remote conditions of his fall are to be found in the milky way, in our federal constitution, or in the early history of Europe. That is to say, alter the milky way, alter the federal constitution, alter the facts of our barbarian ancestry, and the universe would so far be a different universe from what it now is. One fact involved in the difference might be that the particular little street-boy who threw the stone which brought down the sparrow might not find himself opposite the sparrow at that particular moment; or, finding himself there, he might not be in that particular serene and disengaged mood of mind which expressed itself in throwing the stone. But, true as all this is, it would be very foolish for any one who {217}was inquiring the cause of the sparrow's fall to overlook the boy as too personal, proximate, and so to speak anthropomorphic an agent, and to say that the true cause is the federal constitution, the westward migration of the Celtic race, or the structure of the milky way. If we proceeded on that method, we might say with perfect legitimacy that a friend of ours, who had slipped on the ice upon his door-step and cracked his skull, some months after dining with thirteen at the table, died because of that ominous feast. I know, in fact, one such instance; and I might, if I chose, contend with perfect logical propriety that the slip on the ice was no real accident. "There are no accidents," I might say, "for science. The whole history of the world converged to produce that slip. If anything had been left out, the slip would not have occurred just there and then. To say it would is to deny the relations of cause and effect throughout the universe. The real cause of the death was not the slip, but the conditions which engendered the slip,—and among them his having sat at a table, six months previous, one among thirteen. That is truly the reason why he died within the year."
It will soon be seen whose arguments I am, in form, reproducing here. I would fain lay down the truth without polemics or recrimination. But unfortunately we never fully grasp the import of any true statement until we have a clear notion of what the opposite untrue statement would be. The error is needed to set off the truth, much as a dark background is required for exhibiting the brightness of a picture. And the error which I am going to use as a foil to set off what seems to me the truth of my own statements is contained in the philosophy of Mr. Herbert Spencer and {218}his disciples. Our problem is, What are the causes that make communities change from generation to generation,—that make the England of Queen Anne so different from the England of Elizabeth, the Harvard College of to-day so different from that of thirty years ago?
I shall reply to this problem, The difference is due to the accumulated influences of individuals, of their examples, their initiatives, and their decisions. The Spencerian school replies, The changes are irrespective of persons, and independent of individual control. They are due to the environment, to the circumstances, the physical geography, the ancestral conditions, the increasing experience of outer relations; to everything, in fact, except the Grants and the Bismarcks, the Joneses and the Smiths.

Now, I say that these theorizers are guilty of precisely the same fallacy as he who should ascribe the death of his friend to the dinner with thirteen, or the fall of the sparrow to the milky way. Like the dog in the fable, who drops his real bone to snatch at its image, they drop the real causes to snatch at others, which from no possible human point of view are available or attainable. Their fallacy is a practical one. Let us see where it lies. Although I believe in free-will myself, I will waive that belief in this discussion, and assume with the Spencerians the predestination of all human actions. On that assumption I gladly allow that were the intelligence investigating the man's or the sparrow's death omniscient and omnipresent, able to take in the whole of time and space at a single glance, there would not be the slightest objection to the milky way or the fatal feast being {219}invoked among the sought-for causes. Such a divine intelligence would see instantaneously all the infinite lines of convergence towards a given result, and it would, moreover, see impartially: it would see the fatal feast to be as much a condition of the sparrow's death as of the man's; it would see the boy with the stone to be as much a condition of the man's fall as of the sparrow's.
The human mind, however, is constituted on an entirely different plan. It has no such power of universal intuition. Its finiteness obliges it to see but two or three things at a time. If it wishes to take wider sweeps it has to use 'general ideas,' as they are called, and in so doing to drop all concrete truths. Thus, in the present case, if we as men wish to feel the connection between the milky way and the boy and the dinner and the sparrow and the man's death, we can do so only by falling back on the enormous emptiness of what is called an abstract proposition. We must say, All things in the world are fatally predetermined, and hang together in the adamantine fixity of a system of natural law. But in the vagueness of this vast proposition we have lost all the concrete facts and links; and in all practical matters the concrete links are the only things of importance. The human mind is essentially partial. It can be efficient at all only by picking out what to attend to, and ignoring everything else,—by narrowing its point of view. Otherwise, what little strength it has is dispersed, and it loses its way altogether. Man always wants his curiosity gratified for a particular purpose. If, in the case of the sparrow, the purpose is punishment, it would be idiotic to wander off from the cats, boys, and other possible agencies close by in the street, to {220}survey the early Celts and the milky way: the boy would meanwhile escape. And if, in the case of the unfortunate man, we lose ourselves in contemplation of the thirteen-at-table mystery, and fail to notice the ice on the step and cover it with ashes, some other poor fellow, who never dined out in his life, may slip on it in coming to the door, and fall and break his head too.
It is, then, a necessity laid upon us as human beings to limit our view. In mathematics we know how this method of ignoring and neglecting quantities lying outside of a certain range has been adopted in the differential calculus. The calculator throws out all the 'infinitesimals' of the quantities he is considering. He treats them (under certain rules) as if they did not exist. In themselves they exist perfectly all the while; but they are as if they did not exist for the purposes of his calculation. Just so an astronomer, in dealing with the tidal movements of the ocean, takes no account of the waves made by the wind, or by the pressure of all the steamers which day and night are moving their thousands of tons upon its surface. Just so the marksman, in sighting his rifle, allows for the motion of the wind, but not for the equally real motion of the earth and solar system. Just so a business man's punctuality may overlook an error of five minutes, while a physicist, measuring the velocity of light, must count each thousandth of a second.
There are, in short, different cycles of operation in nature; different departments, so to speak, relatively independent of one another, so that what goes on at any moment in one may be compatible with almost any condition of things at the same time in the next. The mould on the biscuit in the store-room of a {221}man-of-war vegetates in absolute indifference to the nationality of the flag, the direction of the voyage, the weather, and the human dramas that may go on on board; and a mycologist may study it in complete abstraction from all these larger details. Only by so studying it, in fact, is there any chance of the mental concentration by which alone he may hope to learn something of its nature. On the other hand, the captain who in manoeuvring the vessel through a naval fight should think it necessary to bring the mouldy biscuit into his calculations would very likely lose the battle by reason of the excessive 'thoroughness' of his mind.
The causes which operate in these incommensurable cycles are connected with one another only if we take the whole universe into account. For all lesser points of view it is lawful—nay, more, it is for human wisdom necessary—to regard them as disconnected and irrelevant to one another.
生成:
Certainly. I'll craft a philosophical passage based on the summary you've provided, expanding on the key ideas and arguments presented. Here's a 1585-word philosophical passage:

On the Practicality of Causation: A Critique of Universal Interconnectedness

In the vast tapestry of existence, every thread is interwoven with countless others, creating a complex web of causality that spans the entirety of the cosmos. From the grandest celestial bodies to the tiniest subatomic particles, all things are, in some measure, connected. This universal interconnectedness has long been a subject of fascination for philosophers and scientists alike, inspiring awe at the intricate dance of cause and effect that governs our reality.

However, while the concept of universal interconnectedness may be philosophically compelling, it presents significant challenges when applied to practical human understanding and problem-solving. The human mind, despite its remarkable capabilities, is fundamentally limited in its capacity to process and comprehend the infinite complexity of the universe. Our cognitive faculties have evolved to navigate the immediate world around us, to solve concrete problems, and to make decisions based on relevant, proximate information.

It is within this context that we must critically examine the philosophical stance advocated by Herbert Spencer and his intellectual disciples. Spencer's philosophy, often characterized as a form of cosmic evolutionism, emphasizes the importance of broad, sweeping causes in explaining phenomena. While this approach may offer a grand, unifying vision of the universe, it often does so at the expense of practical utility and actionable understanding.

Consider, for a moment, the fall of a sparrow from the sky. In the Spencerian view, one might be tempted to trace the cause of this event back to the formation of the Milky Way, the evolution of avian species, or perhaps even the socio-economic conditions that led to the development of urban environments where sparrows thrive. While these factors may indeed play a role in the grand scheme of things, they offer little in the way of immediate explanation or practical insight.

In contrast, a more focused approach would consider the proximate cause of the sparrow's fall. Perhaps a child, in a moment of mischief, threw a stone that struck the bird. Or maybe the sparrow, weakened by disease or old age, simply lost its ability to maintain flight. These immediate causes provide us with tangible, actionable information that can inform our understanding and guide our responses.

The importance of this distinction cannot be overstated. Human cognition, by its very nature, is specialized and limited. We have evolved to process and respond to immediate stimuli, to identify patterns in our immediate environment, and to make decisions based on relevant, accessible information. Our brains are not equipped to constantly consider the entire web of cosmic causality in every decision or analysis we make.

This cognitive limitation is not a flaw, but rather a necessary adaptation that allows us to function effectively in the world. By focusing on proximate causes, we can more readily identify problems, formulate solutions, and take meaningful action. If we were to constantly consider all possible causal factors, no matter how remote or tenuous, we would find ourselves paralyzed by the sheer complexity of the universe, unable to make even the simplest decisions or draw the most basic conclusions.

Moreover, the practical limitations of human knowledge and perception make it impossible for us to truly grasp all the causal factors at play in any given situation. Even with the most advanced scientific instruments and methodologies, there will always be factors beyond our ability to measure or comprehend. As such, attempting to account for all possible causes is not only impractical but fundamentally impossible.

This is not to say that broader, more systemic causes should be entirely disregarded. In many fields of study, understanding larger patterns and more distant causal factors can provide valuable insights. However, these broader considerations must be balanced against the need for practical, actionable understanding.

Consider the field of medicine as an example. A doctor treating a patient with a bacterial infection must focus primarily on the immediate cause – the specific pathogen responsible for the illness – and the most effective means of combating it. While factors such as the patient's genetic predispositions, lifestyle choices, or even broader societal issues like antibiotic resistance may be relevant, the primary focus must remain on the proximate cause and immediate treatment options.

Similarly, in the realm of social sciences, while it may be intellectually stimulating to trace social phenomena back to distant historical events or broad cultural trends, the most effective interventions often come from addressing immediate, tangible causes. A social worker attempting to address issues of poverty in a community will likely find more success in focusing on immediate factors such as job availability, education access, and local economic conditions rather than pontificating on the historical roots of economic inequality.

This focused approach to causality finds parallels in other fields of human inquiry. In mathematics and physics, for instance, it is common practice to simplify complex systems by excluding minor variables or factors deemed insignificant to the problem at hand. This process of abstraction and simplification allows for more manageable calculations and clearer insights into the core dynamics of a system.

For example, when calculating the trajectory of a projectile, a physicist might choose to ignore factors such as air resistance or the curvature of the Earth if their effects are negligible within the scope of the problem. This simplification does not negate the existence or potential importance of these factors in other contexts, but rather acknowledges the practical necessity of focusing on the most relevant variables for the task at hand.

In essence, this approach to causality is not about denying the interconnectedness of all things, but rather about recognizing the practical limitations of human cognition and the necessity of focused inquiry. It is an acknowledgment that while everything may be connected in some abstract sense, not all connections are equally relevant or useful in every context.

This perspective also aligns with the philosophical concept of epistemic humility – the recognition of the limits of our knowledge and understanding. By focusing on proximate causes and immediate factors, we implicitly acknowledge that there are broader causal networks beyond our full comprehension. This humility can serve as a guard against intellectual hubris and the tendency to oversimplify complex phenomena.

However, it is crucial to note that the emphasis on proximate causes should not be mistaken for a call to ignore broader contexts or systemic issues. Rather, it is an argument for a balanced approach that recognizes the importance of immediate, actionable causes while remaining aware of larger patterns and more distant factors.

In practice, this might involve a multi-tiered approach to problem-solving and analysis. At the most immediate level, we focus on proximate causes and direct interventions. At broader levels, we consider larger patterns, systemic issues, and more distant causal factors. The key is to maintain a clear hierarchy of relevance, prioritizing those factors that are most immediately pertinent to the problem at hand.

This approach also allows for a more nuanced understanding of causality itself. Rather than viewing causation as a simple, linear chain of events, we can conceptualize it as a complex network of interacting factors, each with varying degrees of influence and relevance depending on the specific context and scale of analysis.

For instance, in analyzing a social phenomenon like crime rates in a city, we might consider immediate factors such as poverty levels, policing strategies, and educational opportunities. At a broader level, we might examine cultural attitudes, historical patterns of urban development, and national economic trends. By maintaining this hierarchical approach, we can develop a more comprehensive understanding while still prioritizing the most actionable and relevant factors.

Furthermore, this perspective on causality has important implications for how we approach knowledge and education. Instead of attempting to teach or learn "everything about everything," we can focus on developing the skills to identify and analyze relevant causal factors within specific contexts. This involves not just accumulating facts, but cultivating the ability to discern which factors are most pertinent to a given situation and how they interact.

In conclusion, while the interconnectedness of all things in the universe is a profound and awe-inspiring concept, its practical application in human understanding and problem-solving is limited. The philosophy espoused by Herbert Spencer and his followers, which emphasizes broad, remote causes over immediate ones, fails to account for the practical limitations of human cognition and the necessity of focused inquiry.

Instead, we must recognize the importance of prioritizing proximate causes and immediate factors in our analyses and problem-solving efforts. This approach allows us to make effective use of our cognitive capabilities, to take meaningful action in the face of complex problems, and to develop practical, actionable understanding of the world around us.

At the same time, we must maintain an awareness of broader contexts and more distant causal factors, integrating them into our understanding in a hierarchical manner that respects their relative relevance and influence. By doing so, we can strike a balance between the grand vision of universal interconnectedness and the practical necessities of human cognition and action.

In essence, this philosophy of practical causation is not a rejection of the idea that everything is connected, but rather a recognition of the need to focus our limited cognitive resources on those connections that are most relevant and actionable in any given context. It is an approach that respects both the vastness of the cosmos and the practical limitations of the human mind, allowing us to navigate the complexity of existence with both humility and effectiveness.
summary: The passage argues that while everything in the universe is interconnected, it is impractical and unproductive for humans to consider all possible causes when trying to explain specific events. The author critiques the philosophy of Herbert Spencer and his followers, who emphasize the broad, remote causes over immediate, proximate ones. The author asserts that human cognition is limited and specialized, requiring a focus on immediate, concrete causes to be effective. For instance, attributing a sparrow's fall solely to broad factors like the Milky Way or a historical event ignores the immediate cause, such as a boy throwing a stone. The author underlines the necessity of narrowing our focus to relevant causes within a particular scope, similar to how mathematicians and scientists simplify their calculations by excluding minor factors. This focused approach is essential for practical problem-solving and understanding.

Thus, in the present case, if we as men wish to feel the connection between the milky way and the boy and the dinner and the sparrow and the man's death, we can do so only by falling back on the enormous emptiness of what is called an abstract proposition. We must say, All things in the world are fatally predetermined, and hang together in the adamantine fixity of a system of natural law. But in the vagueness of this vast proposition we have lost all the concrete facts and links; and in all practical matters the concrete links are the only things of importance. The human mind is essentially partial. It can be efficient at all only by picking out what to attend to, and ignoring everything else,—by narrowing its point of view. Otherwise, what little strength it has is dispersed, and it loses its way altogether. Man always wants his curiosity gratified for a particular purpose. If, in the case of the sparrow, the purpose is punishment, it would be idiotic to wander off from the cats, boys, and other possible agencies close by in the street, to {220}survey the early Celts and the milky way: the boy would meanwhile escape. And if, in the case of the unfortunate man, we lose ourselves in contemplation of the thirteen-at-table mystery, and fail to notice the ice on the step and cover it with ashes, some other poor fellow, who never dined out in his life, may slip on it in coming to the door, and fall and break his head too.
It is, then, a necessity laid upon us as human beings to limit our view. In mathematics we know how this method of ignoring and neglecting quantities lying outside of a certain range has been adopted in the differential calculus. The calculator throws out all the 'infinitesimals' of the quantities he is considering. He treats them (under certain rules) as if they did not exist. In themselves they exist perfectly all the while; but they are as if they did not exist for the purposes of his calculation. Just so an astronomer, in dealing with the tidal movements of the ocean, takes no account of the waves made by the wind, or by the pressure of all the steamers which day and night are moving their thousands of tons upon its surface. Just so the marksman, in sighting his rifle, allows for the motion of the wind, but not for the equally real motion of the earth and solar system. Just so a business man's punctuality may overlook an error of five minutes, while a physicist, measuring the velocity of light, must count each thousandth of a second.
There are, in short, different cycles of operation in nature; different departments, so to speak, relatively independent of one another, so that what goes on at any moment in one may be compatible with almost any condition of things at the same time in the next. The mould on the biscuit in the store-room of a {222}man-of-war vegetates in absolute indifference to the nationality of the flag, the direction of the voyage, the weather, and the human dramas that may go on on board; and a mycologist may study it in complete abstraction from all these larger details. Only by so studying it, in fact, is there any chance of the mental concentration by which alone he may hope to learn something of its nature. On the other hand, the captain who in manoeuvring the vessel through a naval fight should think it necessary to bring the mouldy biscuit into his calculations would very likely lose the battle by reason of the excessive 'thoroughness' of his mind.
The causes which operate in these incommensurable cycles are connected with one another only if we take the whole universe into account. For all lesser points of view it is lawful—nay, more, it is for human wisdom necessary—to regard them as disconnected and irrelevant to one another.
summary: The passage argues that while everything in the universe is interconnected, it is impractical and unproductive for humans to consider all possible causes when trying to explain specific events. The author critiques the philosophy of Herbert Spencer and his followers, who emphasize the broad, remote causes over immediate, proximate ones. The author asserts that human cognition is limited and specialized, requiring a focus on immediate, concrete causes to be effective. For instance, attributing a sparrow's fall solely to broad factors like the Milky Way or a historical event ignores the immediate cause, such as a boy throwing a stone. The author underlines the necessity of narrowing our focus to relevant causes within a particular scope, similar to how mathematicians and scientists simplify their calculations by excluding minor factors. This focused approach is essential for practical problem-solving and understanding.

原文:
It will be best to prepare the ground for my thesis by a few very general remarks on the method of getting at scientific truth. It is a common platitude that a complete acquaintance with any one thing, however small, would require a knowledge of the entire universe. Not a sparrow falls to the ground but some of the remote conditions of his fall are to be found in the milky way, in our federal constitution, or in the early history of Europe. That is to say, alter the milky way, alter the federal constitution, alter the facts of our barbarian ancestry, and the universe would so far be a different universe from what it now is. One fact involved in the difference might be that the particular little street-boy who threw the stone which brought down the sparrow might not find himself opposite the sparrow at that particular moment; or, finding himself there, he might not be in that particular serene and disengaged mood of mind which expressed itself in throwing the stone. But, true as all this is, it would be very foolish for any one who {217}was inquiring the cause of the sparrow's fall to overlook the boy as too personal, proximate, and so to speak anthropomorphic an agent, and to say that the true cause is the federal constitution, the westward migration of the Celtic race, or the structure of the milky way. If we proceeded on that method, we might say with perfect legitimacy that a friend of ours, who had slipped on the ice upon his door-step and cracked his skull, some months after dining with thirteen at the table, died because of that ominous feast. I know, in fact, one such instance; and I might, if I chose, contend with perfect logical propriety that the slip on the ice was no real accident. "There are no accidents," I might say, "for science. The whole history of the world converged to produce that slip. If anything had been left out, the slip would not have occurred just there and then. To say it would is to deny the relations of cause and effect throughout the universe. The real cause of the death was not the slip, but the conditions which engendered the slip,—and among them his having sat at a table, six months previous, one among thirteen. That is truly the reason why he died within the year."
It will soon be seen whose arguments I am, in form, reproducing here. I would fain lay down the truth without polemics or recrimination. But unfortunately we never fully grasp the import of any true statement until we have a clear notion of what the opposite untrue statement would be. The error is needed to set off the truth, much as a dark background is required for exhibiting the brightness of a picture. And the error which I am going to use as a foil to set off what seems to me the truth of my own statements is contained in the philosophy of Mr. Herbert Spencer and {218}his disciples. Our problem is, What are the causes that make communities change from generation to generation,—that make the England of Queen Anne so different from the England of Elizabeth, the Harvard College of to-day so different from that of thirty years ago?
I shall reply to this problem, The difference is due to the accumulated influences of individuals, of their examples, their initiatives, and their decisions. The Spencerian school replies, The changes are irrespective of persons, and independent of individual control. They are due to the environment, to the circumstances, the physical geography, the ancestral conditions, the increasing experience of outer relations; to everything, in fact, except the Grants and the Bismarcks, the Joneses and the Smiths.

Now, I say that these theorizers are guilty of precisely the same fallacy as he who should ascribe the death of his friend to the dinner with thirteen, or the fall of the sparrow to the milky way. Like the dog in the fable, who drops his real bone to snatch at its image, they drop the real causes to snatch at others, which from no possible human point of view are available or attainable. Their fallacy is a practical one. Let us see where it lies. Although I believe in free-will myself, I will waive that belief in this discussion, and assume with the Spencerians the predestination of all human actions. On that assumption I gladly allow that were the intelligence investigating the man's or the sparrow's death omniscient and omnipresent, able to take in the whole of time and space at a single glance, there would not be the slightest objection to the milky way or the fatal feast being {219}invoked among the sought-for causes. Such a divine intelligence would see instantaneously all the infinite lines of convergence towards a given result, and it would, moreover, see impartially: it would see the fatal feast to be as much a condition of the sparrow's death as of the man's; it would see the boy with the stone to be as much a condition of the man's fall as of the sparrow's.
The human mind, however, is constituted on an entirely different plan. It has no such power of universal intuition. Its finiteness obliges it to see but two or three things at a time. If it wishes to take wider sweeps it has to use 'general ideas,' as they are called, and in so doing to drop all concrete truths. Thus, in the present case, if we as men wish to feel the connection between the milky way and the boy and the dinner and the sparrow and the man's death, we can do so only by falling back on the enormous emptiness of what is called an abstract proposition. We must say, All things in the world are fatally predetermined, and hang together in the adamantine fixity of a system of natural law. But in the vagueness of this vast proposition we have lost all the concrete facts and links; and in all practical matters the concrete links are the only things of importance. The human mind is essentially partial. It can be efficient at all only by picking out what to attend to, and ignoring everything else,—by narrowing its point of view. Otherwise, what little strength it has is dispersed, and it loses its way altogether. Man always wants his curiosity gratified for a particular purpose. If, in the case of the sparrow, the purpose is punishment, it would be idiotic to wander off from the cats, boys, and other possible agencies close by in the street, to {220}survey the early Celts and the milky way: the boy would meanwhile escape. And if, in the case of the unfortunate man, we lose ourselves in contemplation of the thirteen-at-table mystery, and fail to notice the ice on the step and cover it with ashes, some other poor fellow, who never dined out in his life, may slip on it in coming to the door, and fall and break his head too.
It is, then, a necessity laid upon us as human beings to limit our view. In mathematics we know how this method of ignoring and neglecting quantities lying outside of a certain range has been adopted in the differential calculus. The calculator throws out all the 'infinitesimals' of the quantities he is considering. He treats them (under certain rules) as if they did not exist. In themselves they exist perfectly all the while; but they are as if they did not exist for the purposes of his calculation. Just so an astronomer, in dealing with the tidal movements of the ocean, takes no account of the waves made by the wind, or by the pressure of all the steamers which day and night are moving their thousands of tons upon its surface. Just so the marksman, in sighting his rifle, allows for the motion of the wind, but not for the equally real motion of the earth and solar system. Just so a business man's punctuality may overlook an error of five minutes, while a physicist, measuring the velocity of light, must count each thousandth of a second.
There are, in short, different cycles of operation in nature; different departments, so to speak, relatively independent of one another, so that what goes on at any moment in one may be compatible with almost any condition of things at the same time in the next. The mould on the biscuit in the store-room of a {223}man-of-war vegetates in absolute indifference to the nationality of the flag, the direction of the voyage, the weather, and the human dramas that may go on on board; and a mycologist may study it in complete abstraction from all these larger details. Only by so studying it, in fact, is there any chance of the mental concentration by which alone he may hope to learn something of its nature. On the other hand, the captain who in manoeuvring the vessel through a naval fight should think it necessary to bring the mouldy biscuit into his calculations would very likely lose the battle by reason of the excessive 'thoroughness' of his mind.
The causes which operate in these incommensurable cycles are connected with one another only if we take the whole universe into account. For all lesser points of view it is lawful—nay, more, it is for human wisdom necessary—to regard them as disconnected and irrelevant to one another.
